trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP uses a dual-trigger mechanism where a meteorological forecast (Trigger 1) must be met before a hydrological forecast (Trigger 2) is evaluated. Trigger 2 formally activates the EAP and initiates the majority of early actions, while Trigger 1 allows for preliminary readiness activities.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: If during the third day of the forecasted lead time the event decreases in intensity to a tropical disturbance, or if the event abruptly changes its predicted trajectory according to the competent forecasting authorities, all actions planned and/or underway under the EAP must be halted immediately.

trigger_statement_1.statement: CENAOS or NOAA issues issues a forecast with ≥60 per cent probability that a tropical storm (≥34 knots) or stronger will reach the alert zone within 3 to 5 days.
thresholds: ≥60% probability of a tropical storm (≥34 knots) or stronger
3 to 5 days lead time
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: CENAOS or NOAA
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Alert zone in Honduras
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Communication and coordination activities, community preparedness messaging, and readiness checks.

trigger_statement_2.statement: When the GEOGLOWS/GloFAS model indicates a ≥50 per cent probability of river flooding with a 10-year return period in high-risk flood zones, within a 3-day lead time.
thresholds: ≥50% probability of river flooding
10-year return period
3-day lead time
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: High-risk flood zones in Honduras (e.g., Ulúa, Chamelecón, Patuca, Choluteca, Humuya, Cangrejal, Coco, and Segovia basins)
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: Trigger 1 must be met in order to reach Trigger 2, which formally activates the EAP.
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Initiation of most early actions including distribution of multi-purpose cash transfers (PTM) and provision of 72-hour WASH kits.

trigger_mechanism.description: The sEAP uses a single-trigger mechanism based on the INFLOW-AI machine learning model which predicts the maximum flood extent of the White Nile/Sudd wetlands two months in advance. The model runs every 10 days (dekads) from June to December to provide updated forecasts.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: This sEAP does not have stop mechanism, the flooding is slow-onset wetland flooding rather than sudden onset flooding, and all actions will be implemented as soon as the sEAP is triggered.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The sEAP will be activated between 1 June and 30 September if the statistical model predicts the change in the Sudd inundation extent from the seasonal minimum to the forecasted maximum extent over the next two months to be greater than 5% then the early actions will be activated.
thresholds: Change in Sudd inundation extent from the seasonal minimum to the forecasted maximum extent over the next two months > 5%
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: INFLOW-AI model (developed through the INFLOW project, hosted on JASMIN)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: White Nile Basin and Sudd Wetland (Central Equatoria, Jonglei, Pibor, Upper Nile, Unity, Ruweng, Lakes, Warrap, Northern Bahr el Ghazal, and Abyei)
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Refresher training for staff and volunteers; procurement and prepositioning of essential household items; beneficiary selection and registration one month ahead of the peak of flooding.

trigger_mechanism.description: The sEAP uses a tiered activation model consisting of Phase 1 (Monitoring), Tier 1 (Forecast-Informed Readiness/Pre-activation), and Tier 2 (Observational and Full Activation). It is based on seasonal outlooks, short-term rainfall/cyclone forecasts, exposure analysis, and real-time river gauge monitoring.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: All actions will be suspended if DCCMS daily forecasts indicate a reduction in anticipated rainfall amounts.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Phase 1: Monitoring of the trigger will be initiated when the Department of Climate Change and Meteorological Services issues a seasonal weather outlook indicating normal to above-normal rainfall, with a high probability of wetter-than-average conditions expected between November and March. Phase 2: The Simplified Early Action Protocol is pre-activated when the DCCMS issues an alert followed by a warning, triggering Tier 1 – Forecast-Informed Readiness. The sEAP will be fully activated for Early Actions under Tier 2 – Observational and Activation when river gauge readings exceed the alert stage at ≥2 stations or inundation modelling projects ≥30% of households affected.
thresholds: Seasonal rainfall totals exceeding 800 mm to 1,200 mm
Rainfall forecast of ≥100–150 mm within 72 hours in key basins
Cyclone forecast predicting ≥100 mm of rainfall within 24 hours in flood-prone districts
Rainfall forecast combined with exposure analysis showing ≥30% of households at risk
River gauge readings exceed the alert stage at ≥2 stations (real-time)
Inundation modelling projects ≥30% of households affected in flood-risk zones
Shire River Basin (Mwanza Gauging Station): 100 mm
Lake Chilwa Basin: 150 mm
Salima/Linthipe/Rifidzi: 100 mm
North Rukuru Catchment (Virauri Gauging Station): 100 mm
South Rukuru Catchment (South Rukuru Bridge Gauging Station): 100 mm
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Department of Climate Change and Meteorological Services (DCCMS)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Flood prone districts in Malawi (Chikwawa, Nsanje, Phalombe, Zomba, Blantyre) and specific catchment areas (Shire River, Lake Chilwa, Salima/Linthipe/Rifidzi, North/South Rukuru).
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: Tiered system where Phase 1 (Monitoring) precedes Tier 1 (Pre-activation), which precedes Tier 2 (Full Activation). Tier 1 is triggered when an alert is followed by a warning.
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Readiness: Community awareness, staff/volunteer orientation on risk monitoring, simulations, and procurement of sandbags, shovels, and cement. Pre-activation: Cleaning drainage systems, implementing feedback mechanisms, prepositioning National Response Teams (NRT), and updating implementation strategies.

trigger_mechanism.description: The sEAP adopts a staged intervention using separate triggers to initiate three consecutive phases of action (Phase 1, Phase 2, and Phase 3) based on the geographic location and severity of cholera cases.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: The sEAP does not include a traditional stop mechanism but uses a scale-down mechanism at each phase. If outbreaks are contained or do not spread, activities can be tapered off or sustained at the current phase without proceeding to the next.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Phase 1: Trigger: A confirmed cholera case in any district of the country will trigger... Phase 2: Trigger A case confirmed in Harare will trigger... Phase 3: Trigger Evidence of community transmission in Harare and spread to additional districts
thresholds: Confirmed cholera case in any district (Vibrio Cholerae 01 or 0139 by culture or PCR)
Confirmed cholera case in Harare
Evidence of community transmission in Harare
Spread to additional districts
Thresholds generated by local clinics for ORP deployment
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Ministry of Health and Child Care (MoHCC)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Zimbabwe (National) with specific focus on Harare urban hotspots
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Phase 1: Deploy mobile Surge Team for investigations and BORT training; deploy BORT teams in Harare for messaging and environmental surveys. Phase 2: Support RRT investigations; deploy BORT with NFIs; distribute inline chlorinator tablets; initiate DREF development. Phase 3: Deploy BORT with NFIs and establish Oral Rehydration Points (ORPs).

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP uses a dual-trigger mechanism. The first trigger (pre-season) is for logistical preparation and coordination, while the second trigger (short-term) activates field-level early actions. The second trigger can be activated independently of the first to ensure maximum responsiveness to imminent threats.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Déclencheur de pré-saison : Prévision par le CEPMMT SEAS5 d'une probabilité de 40 % ou plus que les précipitations totales saisonnières soient supérieures à la normale. En d'autres termes, il s'agit d'une probabilité de 40 % ou plus pour le tercile supérieur.
trigger_statement_1.statement_english: Pre-season trigger: Forecast by ECMWF SEAS5 of a 40% or higher probability that total seasonal rainfall will be above normal. In other words, a 40% or higher probability for the upper tercile.
thresholds: 40% or higher probability of seasonal rainfall being above normal (upper tercile)
Seasonal total for July-August-September (JAS) above normal
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: ECMWF (CEPMMT) SEAS5, ONM, ACMAD / AGRHYMET
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Mauritania (specifically Trarza, Brakna, Gorgol, and Guidimakha)
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Logistical preparation, pre-positioning of resources, training of volunteers, and local coordination.

trigger_statement_2.statement: 5 jours - Prévision de précipitations extrêmes Déclencheur : Les prévisions de l'ECMWF pour un EFI > 0,8 et de l'ONM prévoient une quantité de précipitations supérieure à 25 mm pour les 5 prochains jours. La SONADER dispose d’un réseau des stations hydrométriques qui permet de suivre la situation hydrologique du fleuve en période de crue et de décrue.
trigger_statement_2.statement_english: 5 days - Extreme Precipitation Forecast Trigger: ECMWF forecasts for an EFI > 0.8 and ONM forecasts predicting a rainfall amount greater than 25 mm for the next 5 days. SONADER has a network of hydrometric stations to monitor the river's hydrological situation during flood and recession periods.
thresholds: ECMWF Extreme Forecast Index (EFI) > 0.8
ONM forecast of rainfall > 25 mm in the next 5 days
Hydrological monitoring of river levels via SONADER stations
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: Can be activated independently of the pre-season trigger if conditions are met.
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Implementation of early actions on the ground: assembly of emergency shelters, evacuation of at-risk households to host sites, distribution of sandbags and tools for house protection, distribution of NFI/WASH kits (buckets, jerry cans, water purification products), distribution of mosquito nets, and awareness campaigns.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP uses a multi-stage trigger system consisting of Pre-Activation and Activation phases. The Indus River is divided into three stretches and six sections, each with specific thresholds based on real-time water flow levels, 24-hour forecasts (Bulletin B), and observed outflows. Pre-activation primarily relies on GloFAS (Global Flood Awareness System) or weekly weather outlooks, while activation is based on specific discharge thresholds at gauging stations provided by FFD, PMD, and PID.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: The EAP does not include a stop mechanism once early action is initiated because the reliance on 24-hour lead time forecasts and real-time observations minimizes uncertainty. However, evacuation support is only activated when observed flood outflows exceed specific thresholds.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Section 1: Kabul & Swat River (Lead Time: 6 hours): The trigger for Nowshera district will be reached when the observed flood flows in the Kabul River at Nowshera station, as reported by FFD are at a very high flood level (i.e., over 200,000 cusec), while the trigger for Charsada district is reached when the observed flows in the Swat River at Munda Headworks as reported by PID are at a very high flood level (i.e., over 150,000 cusec).
thresholds: Observed flood flows in Kabul River at Nowshera > 200,000 cusec
Observed flows in Swat River at Munda Headworks > 150,000 cusec
Pre-activation: Weekly weather outlooks from PMD
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: FFD (Flood Forecast Division), PID (Punjab Irrigation Department), PMD (Pakistan Meteorological Department)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Section 1: Kabul & Swat River (Nowshera and Charsada districts)
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Continuous monitoring and validation by PRCS with technical support from RCCC; volunteer mobilization; coordination with government authorities.

trigger_statement_2.statement: Section 2: Indus River - Tarbela to Taunsa (Lead Time 48 hours): The trigger will be reached when Bulletin B i.e., Quantitative flood forecast at gauging stations from the FFD predicts: Flood inflows in Indus at Tarbela of 400,000 cusecs or above in the next 24 hours or High flood inflows in the Indus at Kalabagh of 500,000 cusecs or above in the next 24 hours or High flood inflows in the Indus at Chashma of 550,000 cusecs or above in the next 24 hours.
thresholds: Forecast flood inflows in Indus at Tarbela >= 400,000 cusecs in next 24 hours
Forecast high flood inflows in Indus at Kalabagh >= 500,000 cusecs in next 24 hours
Forecast high flood inflows in Indus at Chashma >= 550,000 cusecs in next 24 hours
Pre-activation: GloFAS predicting 2 to 5-year return period with >70% probability
Evacuation Trigger: Observed river outflows surpass the aforementioned thresholds
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Section 2: Indus River - Tarbela to Taunsa
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: Evacuation of people and livestock is only triggered once observed river outflows surpass the forecast thresholds.
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Pre-activation monitoring; identification of potentially exposed villages using inundation maps and settlement lists.

trigger_statement_3.statement: Section 3: Indus River - Taunsa to Panjnad (Lead Time: 4 days): The activation trigger will be reached when both of the following criteria are met: FFD confirms the observed outflows in Tarbela to be at flood levels above 400,000 cusecs, or observed flood outflows of Indus at Kalabagh are above high flood level i.e., 500,000 cusecs or observed flood outflows of Indus at Chasma is above 550,000 cusecs AND Bulletin B from the FFD predicts high flood inflows of above 550,000 cusecs in the Indus at Taunsa in the next 24 hours.
thresholds: Observed Tarbela outflows > 400,000 cusecs OR Kalabagh > 500,000 cusecs OR Chashma > 550,000 cusecs
Forecast high flood inflows at Taunsa > 550,000 cusecs in next 24 hours
Pre-activation: GloFAS predicting 2 to 5-year return period with >70% probability
Evacuation Trigger: Observed flood outflows in Taunsa > 550,000 cusecs
trigger_statement_3.geographic_scope: Section 3: Indus River - Taunsa to Panjnad
trigger_statement_3.condition_dependency: Dual criteria: Observed upstream outflows must be high AND downstream inflow must be forecast high. Evacuation requires observed Taunsa outflows > 550,000 cusecs.
trigger_statement_3.preliminary_actions: Multipurpose cash assistance targeting registered households in Sections 3 and 5.

trigger_statement_4.statement: Section 4: Chenab River Trimmu to Panjnad (Lead Time: 24 hours): The trigger will be reached when Bulletin B i.e., quantitative flood forecasts from FFD predict high flood inflows of the Chenab River at Trimmu (i.e., 300,000 cusecs or above) in the next 24 hours.
thresholds: Forecast high flood inflows at Trimmu >= 300,000 cusecs in next 24 hours
Pre-activation: GloFAS predicting 2 to 5-year return period with >70% probability
Evacuation Trigger: Observed flood outflows at Trimmu > 300,000 cusecs
trigger_statement_4.geographic_scope: Section 4: Chenab River - Trimmu to Panjnad
trigger_statement_4.condition_dependency: Evacuation is only triggered once observed flood outflows at Trimmu exceed 300,000 cusecs.
trigger_statement_4.preliminary_actions: Early warning dissemination via megaphones and mosque loudspeakers.

trigger_statement_5.statement: Section 5: Indus River - Panjnad to Guddu (Lead Time: 4 days): The trigger will be reached when any of the following criteria are met: The Bulletin B... predicts high flood inflows of above 550,000 cusecs in Taunsa... in the next 24 hours or The Bulletin B... predicts high flood inflows of above 300,000 cusecs in Chenab... at Trimmu or Punjnad in the next 24 hours.
thresholds: Forecast high flood inflows at Taunsa > 550,000 cusecs in next 24 hours
Forecast high flood inflows at Trimmu or Panjnad > 300,000 cusecs in next 24 hours
Pre-activation: GloFAS predicting 2 to 5-year return period with >70% probability
Evacuation Trigger: Observed outflows at Taunsa > 550,000 cusecs OR Panjnad > 300,000 cusecs
trigger_statement_5.geographic_scope: Section 5: Indus River - Panjnad to Guddu
trigger_statement_5.condition_dependency: Evacuation is only triggered once observed outflows at Taunsa or Panjnad exceed thresholds.
trigger_statement_5.preliminary_actions: Multipurpose cash assistance for early harvesting and evacuation subsistence.

trigger_statement_6.statement: Section 6: Guddu to Kotri (Lead Time: 3-5 days): The trigger will be reached when any of the following criteria is met: FFD confirms the observed outflows of the Indus River in Taunsa is above high flood levels of 550,000 cusecs and that of Chenab River at Panjnad is above high flood levels of 300,000 cusecs; OR Bulletin B... predict very high flood inflows in the Indus River at Guddu or Sukkur (i.e., 700,000 cusecs or above) in the next 24 hours; OR FFD confirms that high flood flows are observed in the Indus River at Kotri (i.e., 450,000 cusecs or above) for 3 consecutive days or more.
thresholds: Observed Taunsa > 550,000 cusecs AND Panjnad > 300,000 cusecs
Forecast very high flood inflows at Guddu or Sukkur >= 700,000 cusecs in next 24 hours
Observed high flood flows at Kotri >= 450,000 cusecs for 3+ consecutive days
Pre-activation: GloFAS predicting 2 to 5-year return period with >70% probability
Evacuation Trigger: Observed very high flood levels at Guddu or Sukkur >= 700,000 cusecs
trigger_statement_6.geographic_scope: Section 6: Indus River - Guddu to Kotri
trigger_statement_6.condition_dependency: Evacuation from subsequent tehsils is only triggered once very high flood levels are observed in Guddu or Sukkur.
trigger_statement_6.preliminary_actions: Distribution of WASH materials, hygiene promotion, and mosquito nets at designated evacuation sites.

trigger_mechanism.description: The trigger mechanism is based on the Directorate General of Meteorology (DGM) 2-week precipitation forecast bulletin. The system uses weekly cumulative rainfall maps to identify districts likely to receive significant rainfall. This forecast is coupled with local knowledge of river behavior (natural markers like rocks or trees) and daily heavy rain/flood vigilance bulletins. A modeling tool transforms predicted rainfall into water height and flood zone identification.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The activation trigger will be reached when the weekly forecast bulletin of the river watersheds and the important flood warnings/advisories predict exceptionally high precipitation heights: greater than a cumulative precipitation of 150 mm (i.e. in the category of "abundant" according to the DGM classification, see Appendix)
thresholds: Cumulative precipitation greater than 150 mm per week
Classified as 'abundant' according to DGM classification
Confirmation via local markers (natural beacons like rocks or trees) reaching specific water levels
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Directorate General of Meteorology (DGM) of Madagascar
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Matatana and Manapatrana River basins (Communes of Vohipeno, Vohitrindry, and Anosivelo)
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Dissemination of early warning messages and evacuation bulletins; identification of the most vulnerable communities; validation and registration of beneficiaries; mobilization of volunteers for flood awareness; distribution of roofing sheets (3 days before); disbursement of cash for work (24-48 hours before).

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP is activated based on a seasonal precipitation forecast issued by the national meteorological authority. If the forecast indicates a high probability of rainfall falling into the lower tercile (below normal) for the upcoming quarter, the protocol is triggered to initiate drought-preventive actions.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The triggering criterion will be determined by the Climate Outlook Bulletin issued by the Directorate of Meteorology and Hydrology (DMH), which identifies a 50% or greater probability that rainfall will remain in the lower tercile between December and February, which would imply a reduction in precipitation for the quarter compared to normal levels for that time of year.
thresholds: 50% or greater probability that rainfall will remain in the lower tercile
rainfall below normal levels for the quarter
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Directorate of Meteorology and Hydrology (DMH) - Climate Outlook Bulletin
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Paraguay (national/regional coverage based on DMH forecasts)
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Training of volunteers and staff in vulnerability identification; selection of 285 participating families; training in resilient livelihoods (water, soil, seeds); identification of suppliers for agricultural inputs; rapid survey of community water systems; prepositioning of vegetable seeds and agricultural implements (shade nets, mulching, tools); prepositioning of 700 jerrycans and water quality test kits; signing agreements with financial service providers for cash transfers.

trigger_mechanism.description: The sEAP utilizes a dual-trigger mechanism that can be activated under two scenarios. Scenario 1 involves sequential activation where a drought trigger (Trigger 1) must be met before an epidemiological trigger (Trigger 2). Scenario 2 allows for the independent activation of the epidemiological trigger (Trigger 2) without a preceding drought event.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: The sEAP activation will be stopped if: 1) Confirmed cholera cases are identified within the activated area (shifting to response); 2) Five suspected cholera cases are not identified within a week at the end of the lead time of Trigger 1; 3) During Trigger 1 activation, there is no indication of a decline in surface water resources one month after the start of the drought season compared to the normal season based on Ministry of Water and Energy monitoring.

trigger_statement_1.statement: When the monthly EDRMC disaster report confirms the occurrence of drought affecting 32000 people in any of the 20 identified woredas, with a 3-month lead time.
thresholds: Monthly EDRMC disaster report confirms drought occurrence
Drought affects at least 32,000 people
Occurrence in any of the 20 identified woredas
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Ethiopian Disaster Risk Management Commission (EDRMC)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: 20 identified woredas in Somali Region (Gursum, Erer, Hudet, Kelafo, Moyale, Dolo Ado), South Ethiopia Region (Dasenech), and Tigray Region (Dega Temben, Tahtay Adiyabo)
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: ERCS focal person reviews monthly EDRMC reports to monitor drought incidents; monitoring of surface water resources by Ministry of Water and Energy.

trigger_statement_2.statement: ERCS will activate the second trigger of the sEAP when • one confirmed case is reported by EPHI in a neighboring woreda/district of the 20 identified woredas/districts, within the same country or in a neighboring district of bordering country with a 7-day lead time, or • five suspected cases that qualify the clinical case definition of EPHI are identified within a week in the 20 selected woredas/district with a 7-day lead time.
thresholds: One confirmed cholera case reported by EPHI in a neighboring woreda/district (domestic or bordering country)
Five suspected cholera cases qualifying EPHI clinical definition identified within one week in the 20 selected woredas
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: 20 identified woredas and adjacent neighboring districts
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: Can be activated sequentially after Trigger 1 (Scenario 1) or independently (Scenario 2)
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Weekly review of EPHI disease surveillance reports; EPHI notification of confirmed cases via email; mobilization of volunteers for disinfection and awareness; distribution of NFI kits (water treatment chemicals, soap); provision of water treatment chemicals for households in hotspots using the CATI approach; installation of water containers in public facilities.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP activation is based on weather forecasts from BMD or ECMWF with a 4-day lead time and a 70% or more likelihood of impact. The mechanism requires two specific criteria to be fulfilled simultaneously over a duration of 3 consecutive days, affecting at least three districts.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: The stop mechanism is triggered when a later forecast, issued before the start of early actions, indicates a reduced likelihood of a cold wave event. In such cases, in-kind items are stored for future use, cash interventions are halted, and stakeholders/communities are informed via SMS and community meetings.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Trigger will be activated when BMD forecasts minimum temperature goes below (<=7 0C) or the departure from normal temperature is equal to or below the 2nd percentile (3 to 4 0C) and maximum temperature goes below or equal 5th percentile (18-200C) or wind speed exceed 5th percentile (>5 km/hr) for 3 consecutive days, affecting three or more districts partially (>=50% area of the district).
thresholds: Minimum temperature <= 7°C
Departure from normal temperature <= 2nd percentile (3 to 4°C) with minimum temperature 12°C
Maximum temperature <= 5th percentile (18-20°C)
Wind speed > 5th percentile (>5 km/hr)
Duration: 3 consecutive days
Geographic impact: 3 or more districts partially (>=50% area of the district)
Likelihood: 70% or more
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Bangladesh Meteorological Department (BMD) and ECMWF
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Northwest and northeast parts of Bangladesh (specifically 3 or more districts with >=50% area affected)
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Monitoring weather forecasts (December to February), beneficiary verification, Multi-purpose Cash Grant (MPCG) distribution, distribution of blankets/warm clothes/shawls, community awareness sessions on cold wave risks, and technical guidance for livestock and agricultural protection.

trigger_mechanism.description: The sEAP uses a two-stage trigger system. The first trigger (T1) activates low-cost early actions based on environmental drivers, neighboring outbreaks, or drought EAP activation. The second trigger (T2) activates the full range of early actions based on epidemiological surveillance data and official health confirmations. T2 can be activated independently of T1.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: Scaling down follows a phased approach. Oral Rehydration Points (ORPs) without reported cases for seven consecutive days may be deactivated. Attack rate (AR) thresholds (0.1% to 2% in rural areas; 1% to 5% in urban/IDP settings) determine outbreak status and guide the continuation of actions. The sEAP transitions to response if the outbreak exceeds capacity.

trigger_statement_1.statement: T1 can consist of the following scenarios identified as drivers of AWD/cholera epidemics in Somalia based on historical patterns: 1. A confirmed cholera case or spikes in AWD cases in a neighboring location to the selected PAMIs. 2. Activation of the SRCS drought EAP (MDRSO019) 3. The following amplifying factors occur in a selected PAMI... a. Flooding and extensive rains b. Drought followed by heavy rains c. Drought EAP is activated d. Increased malnutrition rates (GAM cases reaching the threshold of >10%) coinciding with heavy rains, flooding, or droughts
thresholds: Confirmed cholera case or AWD spike in a neighboring location
Activation of SRCS drought EAP (MDRSO019)
Flooding and extensive rains
Drought followed by heavy rains
Global Acute Malnutrition (GAM) cases >10% coinciding with heavy rains, flooding, or droughts
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: SRCS, Ministry for Agricultural Development, National Disaster and Food Reserve Authority (NADFOR), Ministry of Health (MoH), Somalia Acute Malnutrition Projection dashboard
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Garowe and Bosaso (Puntland), Borama and Burao districts (Somaliland)
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Low-cost early actions, readiness interventions, community reporting of amplifying factors, and communication with the SRCS Emergency Operations Centre (EoC).

trigger_statement_2.statement: T2 may be triggered by: 1. A spike in AWD/ADD CBS true signals, such as: a. Doubling of alert thresholds – from at least 5 to at least 10 signals (see alert threshold explanation above) within one week. 2. Confidential information from the MoH indicating a rise in AWD/ADD cases 3. MoH confirmation of AWD/Cholera
thresholds: Doubling of CBS alert thresholds (from at least 5 to at least 10 signals) within one week
Confidential MoH information indicating a rise in AWD/ADD cases
Official MoH confirmation of AWD/Cholera
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: SRCS Community-Based Surveillance (CBS) via Nyss platform, Ministry of Health (MoH), EWARN, DHIS2
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Garowe and Bosaso (Puntland), Borama and Burao districts (Somaliland)
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: Can be activated independently of T1
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Full range of early actions including hygiene promotion, distribution of ORS and Zinc, distribution of Aqua Tabs, facilitating referrals, and Risk Communication and Community Engagement (RCCE).

trigger_mechanism.description: The sEAP uses a single trigger mechanism based on ECMWF forecasts. If the forecast for Tirana meets the defined temperature and duration thresholds with a 50% probability, the protocol is activated for Tirana, Elbasan, and Berat simultaneously, as these cities share identical temperature patterns.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The Heatwave sEAP is triggered in Tirana, Elbasan, and Berat if, with a probability of 50% according to ECMWF, there are at least 3 consecutive days in Tirana where the expected maximum and minimum temperatures are both higher than the 95th percentile of the monthly historical maximum and minimum temperatures of the months of June-September, based on data from 2000 to 2024.
thresholds: Probability of 50% according to ECMWF
At least 3 consecutive days
Expected maximum and minimum temperatures both higher than the 95th percentile of monthly historical maximum and minimum temperatures (June-September, 2000-2024)
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: ECMWF (forecast), IGEO (monitoring and historical data analysis)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Cities of Tirana, Berat, and Elbasan, Albania
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Inform beneficiaries through Greenline calls or SMS on upcoming cheque distribution; Distribute cheques via branches and multifunctional teams; Support in cashing of cheques; Set up Red Cross green line; Conduct proactive 'Heat Remote Check Calls' for vulnerable households.

trigger_mechanism.description: The trigger mechanism is based on a single meteorological threshold (daily maximum temperature) forecasted by the ECMWF ensemble. It operates on a dual-stage timeline: a 7-day lead time for the initial release of funds and a 5-day lead time that serves as a final 'Go/No-Go' confirmation or stop mechanism. Monitoring begins up to two weeks in advance through automated notifications.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: If the median ensemble member of the ECMWF ensemble indicates that the daily maximum temperature at Zahle is not less than 2°C with a lead time of 5 days, the intervention is stopped to prevent unnecessary expenditure.

trigger_statement_1.statement: When the median ensemble member of the ECMWF ensemble indicates that the daily maximum temperature at Zahle is projected to be less than 2°C, with a lead time of 7 days.
thresholds: Daily maximum temperature at Zahle < 2°C
Median ensemble member of the ECMWF ensemble
Lead time of 7 days for fund release
Lead time of 5 days for stop/confirmation
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: ECMWF (European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Zahle, Lebanon
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Convene expert committee, liaise with government counterparts, activate volunteers, and conduct volunteer refreshers between day -7 and day -5. Monitoring starts 2 weeks in advance via ECMWF notifications.

trigger_mechanism.description: The trigger mechanism is a multi-stage system based on two scenarios: meteorological predictions for readiness and epidemiological reports for early action. Readiness is triggered by rainfall forecasts which precede outbreaks, while early action is triggered by specific caseload thresholds during peak months or relative to historical averages.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The Meteorological Department forecasts average rainfall exceeding 100mm in the Western Province.
thresholds: Average rainfall exceeding 100mm
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Meteorological Department
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Western Province (Colombo, Kalutara, and Gampaha districts)
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Elimination of mosquito breeding sites at community level, logistical support for MOH response teams, mass/social media mobilization, and empowering children in school circles to lead monitoring.

trigger_statement_2.statement: The trigger is activated under the following conditions: • Weekly caseload exceeding 1,500 cases in the months of May, June, July and December, and January. OR • If the caseload in the target districts exceeds 1.5 times higher than their average caseload.
thresholds: Weekly caseload exceeding 1,500 cases in May, June, July, December, and January
Caseload in target districts exceeds 1.5 times higher than their average caseload
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: National Dengue Control Unit (NDCU), Ministry of Health (MoH)
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: National (focused on Colombo, Gampaha, Kalutara, Jaffna, and Kandy districts)
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: Activated when epidemiological thresholds are met, typically following the readiness phase or during seasonal peaks.
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: House-to-house surveillance campaigns, volunteer deployment to hospitals, distribution of IEC materials to patients and families, training households on water storage cleaning, and clean-up campaigns in public hotspots.

trigger_mechanism.description: The trigger mechanism is a two-stage system based on lead time. A Readiness trigger is met if conditions are forecasted at a 120-hour lead time (using unofficial forecasts), and an Action trigger is met if conditions are forecasted at a 72-hour lead time (using official track forecasts).

trigger_statement_1.statement: This simplified EAP will be triggered by a tropical cyclone that is forecasted by the Regional Specialized Meteorological Centre (RSMC) in Nadi to be a: Category 4 or 5 while within 250 km of Fiji, or Category 3, 4, or 5 while making landfall in Fiji
thresholds: Category 4 or 5 while within 250 km of Fiji
Category 3, 4, or 5 while making landfall in Fiji
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Regional Specialized Meteorological Centre (RSMC) in Nadi / Fiji Meteorological Services (FMS)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: National level coverage (Fiji), with focus on coastal low-lying areas and 16 branch networks
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Inform relevant Branches; Activation of internal processes for the release of funds; Prepositioning of funds to divisional teams; Notify logistics service providers; Movement of resources (staff and volunteers); Checking of pre-positioned items; Stakeholder coordination meetings; Confirmation of target communities and households.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP is activated based on a 5-day impact-based weather forecast issued by the Tanzania Meteorological Authority (TMA). It uses a single-trigger mechanism with multiple spatial and temporal conditions that must be met simultaneously.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: Full activation is avoided if the forecast is downgraded below the severe threshold three or more days before the event. In such cases, preparedness and early warning activities continue only in areas where alerts remain.

trigger_statement_1.statement:
The EAP is triggered when the following conditions are met: 
• A severe rainfall warning (orange) or major warning (red) is issued in over 10 administrative regions across more than three river basins, lasting at least two consecutive days. 
• At least one advisory-level warning (yellow) is present on any of the remaining days within the five-day forecast.
thresholds: Severe rainfall warning (orange) or major warning (red)
Issued in over 10 administrative regions
Across more than three river basins
Lasting at least two consecutive days
At least one advisory-level warning (yellow) on any of the remaining days within the five-day forecast
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Tanzania Meteorological Authority (TMA)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Tanzania (specifically over 10 administrative regions across more than three river basins)
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Dissemination of early warning messages, community-level cleaning of drainage systems and trenches, pre-positioning and distribution of cleaning tools, support for evacuation of vulnerable individuals, pre-positioning and distribution of WASH supplies (water purification tablets, hygiene kits), activation of EPIC-trained volunteers, and deployment of first aid teams.

trigger_mechanism.description: The sEAP is activated when a recognized authority issues an official document (Act, Bulletin, or Early Alert) indicating that a massive forced displacement has occurred or is imminent, provided the number of victims reaches or is expected to reach department-specific thresholds.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: The Early Action ends once the activities foreseen for each component are fulfilled (estimated duration of 30 days). It is also expected that within this timeframe, violent actions will have ceased and security conditions will allow communities to return to their territories.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The activation of this sEAP will be met when the corresponding institution (Transitional Justice Committee, OCHA or the Ombudsman's Office) issues one of the respective official or activating documents: Act, Bulletin or Early Alert, in which it is indicated that a massive forced displacement caused by the armed conflict has occurred, or the risk of occurrence is imminent, in one or more of the municipalities of the departments that constitute the Colombian Pacific region (Chocó, Valle del Cauca, Cauca or Nariño) that reaches (or may reach) the threshold established in number of displaced victims per department.
thresholds: Chocó: 1,290 people
Cauca: 1,696 people
Nariño: 3,040 people
Valle del Cauca: 2,078 people
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Transitional Justice Committee, OCHA, or the Ombudsman's Office
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Colombian Pacific region (Chocó, Valle del Cauca, Cauca, and Nariño)
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Readiness activities include local first aid and psychosocial workshops, purchase of kits, and inter-institutional monitoring meetings. Pre-positioning includes purchasing hygiene kits, water treatment plants, and storage tanks.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP uses a multi-stage trigger system consisting of a Pre-trigger (Trigger 0), Trigger 1, and Trigger 2. These triggers are based on ENSO signals, seasonal precipitation forecasts, and observed crop losses/dry spells. There is no dependency between Trigger 0 and Trigger 1, and Trigger 2 can be activated even if the previous triggers were not met.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: If the forecast shows a declining risk (e.g., probability drops below 40% by day 10 of the 25-day lead time), an Emergency Operations Meeting will be convened to recommend stopping the activation. Pre-purchased non-food items (NFIs) will be stored, while planned activities for later phases (e.g., cash transfers) will be canceled.

trigger_statement_1.statement: When the ECMWF issues in July an NDJ average forecast of a Nino3.4 index>=0.5K, the pre-trigger is reached and the pre-actions will be started.
thresholds: ECMWF NDJ average Niño3.4 index >= 0.5K
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: ECMWF
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Zambia
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Start pre-actions; readiness activities including training for volunteers, pre-positioning of supplies (WASH kits, seeds), updating vulnerability maps, and awareness campaigns.

trigger_statement_2.statement: When the ECMWF SEAS5 seasonal forecast issued in October forecasts a below average precipitation (with 45% and above probability of the ‘below average’ tercile), the first trigger is reached and the first set of funded early actions will be implemented in anticipation of a failed rainy season.
thresholds: ECMWF SEAS5 seasonal forecast (October) below average precipitation with >= 45% probability of the 'below average' tercile
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Implementation of the first set of funded early actions, including awareness raising, borehole rehabilitation, and distribution of drought-resistant seeds and WASH kits.

trigger_statement_3.statement: When the Ministry of Agriculture CFSI in March-April projects 40% and above losses in the current season and ZMD calculates more than 21 days of no rain higher than 1mm during the period DJFM, the second set of funded early actions will be implemented in anticipation of declining food and economic security.
thresholds: Ministry of Agriculture Crop Forecast Survey Index (CFSI) projects >= 40% crop losses
Zambia Meteorological Department (ZMD) records > 21 consecutive days of no rain (> 1mm) during DJFM
trigger_statement_3.source_authority: Ministry of Agriculture (CFSI) and Zambia Meteorological Department (ZMD)
trigger_statement_3.condition_dependency: Can be activated even if Trigger 0 and Trigger 1 are not met.
trigger_statement_3.preliminary_actions: Implementation of the second set of funded early actions, specifically unconditional cash transfers to vulnerable households.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP is activated based on a single-trigger mechanism when water levels are forecasted to exceed a 5-year return period threshold at key monitoring stations along the Niger and Senegal Rivers.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: A deactivation mechanism is applied if forecasts indicate that flood levels will not reach the critical threshold within three days.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The EAP for river flooding in Mali will be activated when water levels exceed the 5-year return period threshold at key monitoring stations along the Niger and Senegal Rivers, as determined by the National Directorate of Hydraulics and Mali Météo.
thresholds: 5-year return period flood forecast
370 cm in Bamako
859 cm in Kayes
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: National Directorate of Hydraulics (DNH) and Mali Météo
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: High-risk flood-prone areas along the Niger and Senegal Rivers, specifically Mopti, Ségou, Timbuktu, Gao, Kayes, and Bamako.
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Community awareness campaigns, evacuation support, distribution of 20,000 sandbags, reinforcement of dikes, sanitation and hygiene interventions (provision of aquatab tablets and 1,000 emergency mosquito nets), and livelihood protection measures (livestock evacuation and emergency fodder).

trigger_mechanism.description: The trigger system is a multi-stage mechanism based on rainfall forecasts from the National Directorate for Meteorology and Geophysics (DNMG). It consists of a Preparedness phase (Trigger 1) at a 5-day lead time and an Activation phase (Trigger 2) at a 3-day lead time, with a specific 24-hour lead time for evacuation actions. The system uses a color-coded warning scale (Green, Yellow, Orange, Red).

trigger_statement_1.statement: The second trigger will be reached when a 3-day weather forecast from DNMG issues a red warning (extreme rain) in any of the target municipalities for two consecutive days. This means all the relevant pre-agreed early actions will be triggered in the respective municipalities that are likely to receive rainfall with a cumulative total of more than 200mm in next 72 hours. The evacuation early action will only be triggered at the 24-hour lead time.
thresholds: Orange warning (rainfall intensity 10-20mm/hr or 50-100mm/day) in more than three target municipalities for three consecutive days or more in a 5-day forecast period
Cumulative rainfall total of 150 mm or more during the forecasted period of heavy rainfall in the next 5 days
Red warning (rainfall intensity of more than 20 mm/hr or daily total of more than 100mm) in any of the target municipalities for two consecutive days
Cumulative rainfall total of more than 200mm in the next 72 hours
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: National Directorate for Meteorology and Geophysics (DNMG)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Flood risk areas of Manatuto, Viqueque, Manufahi, Covalima, and Oecusse municipalities (excluding Dili)
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: The Activation phase (Trigger 2) follows the Preparedness phase (Trigger 1) as the forecast lead time decreases and intensity increases.
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Preparedness phase (Trigger 1) actions: Map/identify safer areas and routes; Purchase loudspeakers and megaphones; Purchase basic shelter equipment (mattresses, blankets, tarps); Identify households for seed storage drums; Conduct beneficiary selection meetings; Establish agreements with local catering.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP uses a multi-stage trigger mechanism consisting of a 'Pre-activation' phase and an 'Activation' phase. Pre-activation is triggered 6 days before a predicted peak based on rainfall intensity and probability. Activation is triggered 2 to 3 days before the event based on one of two conditions: a high-probability heavy rainfall forecast from BMKG or a specific rainfall threshold reached on the BNPB Prevention Dashboard. The system also incorporates river water level monitoring (Waspada, Siaga, Awas) to validate forecasts.

trigger_statement_1.statement: PMI NHQ will make the activation decision based on BMKG forecasts or BNPB’s Prevention Dashboard as follows: Condition 1: BMKG has issued forecast information for rainfall intensity exceeding 100mm in 24 hours with a probability of 80%... Or Condition 2: BNPB, through the Dashboard Pencegahan, provides information on rainfall exceeding the threshold of 80 mm/day in a specific area. 'Pre-activation' is carried out by utilizing forecast information on rainfall intensity exceeding 50mm in 6 hours with a probability of over 60% during the 6 days prior to the peak.
thresholds: Pre-activation: Rainfall intensity > 50mm in 6 hours with probability > 60%
Activation Condition 1: Rainfall intensity > 100mm in 24 hours with 80% probability
Activation Condition 2: Rainfall exceeding 80 mm/day
Water Level Categories: Waspada (Alert), Siaga (Standby), or Awas (Warning)
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: BMKG (Indonesian Meteorology, Climatology, and Geophysics Agency) and BNPB (National Disaster Management Agency)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Nationwide (Indonesia), with specific analysis for Bengawan Solo, Babura, Barito, and Mahakam watersheds
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Pre-activation activities include monitoring various platforms (seasonal forecasts, BMKG probabilistic forecasts), coordination with stakeholders, volunteer orientation, and procurement/prepositioning of first aid equipment, hygiene kits, and dignity kits.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP uses a conditional dual-trigger system where Trigger 1 (NHC probability) must be met before Trigger 2 (DGOA rainfall forecast) can activate the full EAP. Trigger 1 allows for zero-cost early actions, while Trigger 2 activates the full protocol and funded actions.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Trigger 1: The National Hurricane Center (NHC) issues a greater than 60% chance of a tropical storm or hurricane moving into the General Directorate of the Hazards and Natural Resources Observatory (DGOA) "emergency stage watch area" for the next 7 days. Trigger 2: DGOA forecast of extreme rainfall, associated with a tropical storm or hurricane, exceeding 200 mm accumulated for a 3-day horizon in the months of May through November.
thresholds: Greater than 60% chance of a tropical storm or hurricane (NHC)
Moving into DGOA 'emergency stage watch area'
Exceeding 200 mm accumulated rainfall (DGOA)
3-day horizon
Months of May through November
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: National Hurricane Center (NHC) and General Directorate of the Hazards and Natural Resources Observatory (DGOA)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Departments of Ahuachapán, La Paz, Sonsonate, Morazán, La Unión and Usulután, particularly the Pacific coast and banks of main bodies of water
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: Trigger 1 must be fulfilled to reach Trigger 2; Trigger 2 is the final activator for the EAP
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Trigger 1 allows for early actions that do not require cost for the EAP. Trigger 2 activates full early actions including multipurpose cash transfers and WASH kit distribution.

trigger_mechanism.description: The trigger system is based on the 'Red Button' (Botón Rojo) condition, which monitors specific meteorological and ignition conditions to predict wildfire risk and advance.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: An updated forecast 3 days after receiving the trigger forecast to confirm if conditions are still above the thresholds or if they have lowered their probability of reaching the thresholds defined in the trigger.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Trigger: Activation will be declared when the "Red Button" condition is reached, an ignition probability equal to or greater than 70%, wind speed equal to or greater than 20 Km/h, relative humidity less than 30% in the threatened territory. With 8 days in advance, this forecast must maintain a high probability that vulnerable communities will be reached.
thresholds: Ignition probability equal to or greater than 70%
Wind speed equal to or greater than 20 Km/h
Relative humidity less than 30%
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: National Forestry Corporation (CONAF) - Red Button
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: V Region (Coastal farallón, Intermediate Depression, Cordillera de la Costa) and VII Region (Coastal Zone, Maule Basin, Pre-mountain range) of Chile
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Monitoring of fire advance by CONAF; alerting SENAPRED; training of volunteers in Multipurpose Cash Transfer; identification of regional storage centers; identification of vulnerable populated areas; procurement of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) Kits.

trigger_mechanism.description: The trigger system is a multi-stage mechanism starting with a 10-day pre-activation phase followed by a 5-day activation phase. It is based on Heat Index (HI) values calculated from daily maximum temperature and relative humidity forecasts. Activation is triggered when the HI exceeds the 90th percentile for at least three consecutive days.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: A stop mechanism for high-value early actions (specifically cash) is initiated if the forecasted HI thresholds do not hold true for the corresponding days or if observed daily maximum temperature and humidity do not correspond to the HI thresholds. Cash distribution requires a minimum 48h lead time and is only confirmed when observed HI values and the next two days of forecasts surpass the thresholds.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The Simplified EAP will be activated when: Calculated Heat Index (HI) ≥ 62.6 Yangon / 58.2 Mandalay for more or equal than 3 consecutive days (No unit to HI as it refers to Index Value) is forecasted based on DMH´s forecasts.
thresholds: Heat Index (HI) ≥ 62.6 for Yangon (Kaba Aye)
Heat Index (HI) ≥ 58.2 for Mandalay
Duration of 3 or more consecutive days
HI values corresponding to > 90th percentile for summer months (March-May)
10-day numerical weather prediction from Indian Meteorology Department (IMD) indicating potential heat extremes (Pre-activation stage)
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Department of Meteorology & Hydrology (DMH) of Myanmar and Indian Meteorology Department (IMD)
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: Up to 10 days (Pre-activation) with a 5-day activation window
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Yangon (Kaba Aye) and Mandalay, Myanmar
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Heads up to EC members, verification of beneficiaries, setting up First Aid (FA) posts including shading places and water stands, dissemination of forecasts and awareness messages.

trigger_mechanism.description: The simplified Early Action Protocol is activated based on a forecast from the National Meteorological Agency (ANAM) when a specific temperature threshold is predicted to be exceeded for a minimum duration of three consecutive days.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The simplified PAP is activated if a maximum temperature threshold of 42.4°C for at least three (03) consecutive days is announced by the National Meteorological Agency with a lead time of 4 days compared to the beginning.
thresholds: Maximum temperature of 42.4°C
Duration of at least 3 consecutive days
Exceeding the 90th percentile of the distribution of the hottest month of the year
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: National Meteorological Agency (ANAM)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: City of Ouagadougou, specifically spontaneous housing districts (non-lotis)
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Raising awareness among at-risk communities (lead time 2-0 days); Distribution of WASH kits, dignity kits, food, solar lighting kits, and cooling kits (lead time 4-2 days); Home visits for medical follow-up and care of people with special needs (lead time 2-0 days).

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP is activated based on official reports from IDEAM. It requires two conditions to be met simultaneously: a three-month precipitation forecast showing a 50% probability of below-normal rainfall and a Standardized Precipitation Index (SPI) forecast indicating moderate drought (values <= -1.4) for the same period.

trigger_statement_1.statement: In accordance with the above, this EAP will be activated when IDEAM reports a precipitation forecast (three months) with a probability of 50% that rainfall will be below normal and that the SPI forecast indicates a moderate drought with values equal or below -1.4, for the same forecasted months, in the departments of the Caribbean and Andean region.
thresholds: Precipitation forecast (three months) with a probability of 50% that rainfall will be below normal
Standardized Precipitation Index (SPI) forecast indicating moderate drought with values equal or below -1.4
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: IDEAM (Institute of Hydrology, Meteorology and Environmental Studies)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Departments of the Caribbean and Andean region, Colombia
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Readiness activities: Design and printing of educational materials for livelihood protection, update of feasibility/market studies for Cash and Voucher Assistance (CVA), mapping of Financial Service Providers (FSPs), volunteer training for CVA registration, and Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) workshops. Prepositioning activities: Purchase of nutritional blocks for livestock and hydro-retainers for crops.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP uses a dual-trigger mechanism based on monitoring weather conditions three months in advance. Trigger 1 monitors El Niño (ENSO) conditions in region 3.4, while Trigger 2 monitors quarterly precipitation forecasts. The final selection of intervention zones is determined by overlaying the Trigger 2 forecast onto a historical risk model to identify high-risk municipalities.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: A control mechanism will be evaluated three months after the initiation of the Early Action Protocol (EAP).

trigger_statement_1.statement: When the General Directorate of Threat Observatory and Natural Resources (DGOA) communicates an El Niño event in region 3.4 for the upcoming 3 or 4 months with a 60% probability, based on the official IRI-CPC forecast until April of year (0) or even earlier in year (-1).
thresholds: El Niño event in region 3.4
60% probability
IRI-CPC forecast until April of year (0) or earlier in year (-1)
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: General Directorate of Threat Observatory and Natural Resources (DGOA) / IRI-CPC
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: El Salvador (Region 3.4 for ENSO monitoring)
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: This is the first trigger in a dual-trigger system, often preceding or coinciding with Trigger 2.
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Dissemination of drought alerts to the at-risk population in high-risk municipalities; Hygiene promotion campaign with key messages on treating dehydration and preventing heatstroke.

trigger_statement_2.statement: When the DGOA has issued a quarterly precipitation forecast indicating that accumulated rainfall during May, June, and July will be below normal (33rd percentile).
thresholds: Accumulated rainfall during May, June, and July below normal (33rd percentile)
Severe precipitation deficit associated with the 10th percentile
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: General Directorate of Threat Observatory and Natural Resources (DGOA)
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: El Salvador (specifically the Dry Corridor and high-risk municipalities like Mazahuat and El Carmen)
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: This is the second trigger in a dual-trigger system, used to refine the intervention area and activate implementation actions.
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Awareness workshop on adaptive practices for households with subsistence agro-livelihoods; Unconditional cash transfers tied to training; Unrestricted cash transfers for livestock livelihoods; Awareness workshops on the use of cash transfers; Distribution of unconditional cash transfers for basic needs; Cash transfer satisfaction survey; Assessment, treatment, and distribution of safe drinking water; Workshop on appropriate water use and hygiene; Installation of community storage tanks in schools and health centers; Distribution of family water purification and hygiene kits; Monitoring and evaluation of lessons learned.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP is activated based on a specific temperature forecast issued by the national meteorological authority for the highland regions, requiring a sustained low temperature over a specific duration.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The EAP is activated when the Lesotho Meteorological Services (LMS) issues a forecast of 2oC maximum day temperature or less in the highlands for at least two consecutive days with a maximum lead time of four days to the onset.
thresholds: 2°C maximum day temperature or less
At least two consecutive days
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Lesotho Meteorological Services (LMS)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Highlands of Lesotho
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Readiness and prepositioning activities include: pre-contracting financial service providers; targeting, pre-registration, and verification of beneficiaries; CVA refresher training for volunteers; capacity building of communities on DRR; MoUs with telecommunication and media providers; and prepositioning of snow barrows, snow chains, protective clothing, flags, whistles, and megaphones.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP is activated when any of the three defined trigger statements are met 72 hours before the anticipated landfall of a typhoon. The mechanism uses a combination of impact-based forecasting (510 model) and official meteorological bulletins (PAGASA). The PRC AA Technical Working Group also verifies the potential for high impact and additional conditions before activation.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: As the lead time is 3 days, the EAP does not include a stop mechanism.

trigger_statement_1.statement: This EAP will be activated if 72 hours before the anticipated landfall the 510 model indicates at least three (3) municipalities in a province will have 10 per cent of their houses damaged.
thresholds: At least three (3) municipalities in a province with 10% of houses damaged
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Netherlands Red Cross 510 model / ECMWF
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: 25 targeted provinces across North Luzon, Central Luzon, Bicol, Visayas, and Mindanao
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Identification and pre-registration of beneficiaries; training of chapters, LGUs, and volunteers; simulations; pre-agreements with service providers for SSK materials.

trigger_statement_2.statement: This EAP will be activated if 72 hours before the anticipated typhoon landfall the 510 model indicates a minimum 50 per cent likelihood of the typhoon causing complete damage to over 200,000 houses across the country. Additionally, the EAP will be activated under conditions of a 60 per cent likelihood of complete damage to more than 160,000 houses, or a 70 per cent likelihood of complete damage to more than 90,000 houses, or an 80 per cent likelihood of complete damage to more than 50,000 houses.
thresholds: 50% likelihood of complete damage to over 200,000 houses nationwide
60% likelihood of complete damage to more than 160,000 houses nationwide
70% likelihood of complete damage to more than 90,000 houses nationwide
80% likelihood of complete damage to more than 50,000 houses nationwide
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Early harvesting of matured crops/fish; evacuation of livestock and relocation of assets; installation of Shelter Strengthening Kits (SSK); provision of Cash for Work.

trigger_statement_3.statement: When PAGASA issues a typhoon bulletin with a predicted forecast that a Tropical Cyclone will reach wind speed of a) 185km/h in Central or Northern Luzon (Region 1) or b) 185 km/h in Eastern Visayas, Bicol or Calabarzon (Region 2) or c) 118 km/h in Caraga or Davao regions 72 hours before the expected landfall (Region 3), then this EAP will be activated.
thresholds: 185 km/h wind speed in Central or Northern Luzon
185 km/h wind speed in Eastern Visayas, Bicol, or Calabarzon
118 km/h wind speed in Caraga or Davao regions
trigger_statement_3.source_authority: PAGASA (Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration)
trigger_statement_3.geographic_scope: Central Luzon, Northern Luzon, Eastern Visayas, Bicol, Calabarzon, Caraga, and Davao regions
trigger_statement_3.preliminary_actions: Validation of pre-identified beneficiary lists; orientation for selected beneficiaries; implementation of early harvesting and shelter reinforcement.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP uses a sequenced activation mechanism. A first activation occurs at the seasonal scale in May to initiate preparedness and prepositioning, followed by a second activation at a short-term scale (7 days) for the implementation of direct early actions when extreme rainfall is imminent.

trigger_statement_1.statement: On a seasonal scale (information available in May with a two-month lead-time): above-normal seasonal rainfall forecasts, issued by the National Meteorological Agency (ANAM).
thresholds: Above-normal seasonal rainfall forecasts
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: National Meteorological Agency (ANAM) / PRESASS
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Moyen Chari, Mandoul, Logone Oriental, Tandjilé, Mayo Kebbi West, Salamat
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Briefing of volunteers in targeting and distribution; purchase and storage of agricultural equipment (300 wheelbarrows, 600 shovels, 600 pickaxes, 600 rakes); purchase and storage of 20,000 empty bags for home protection.

trigger_statement_2.statement: Short-scale (7 days lead-time): Weekly EFI index forecasts from the ECMWF model > 0.8 AND ANAM extreme rain forecast.
thresholds: Weekly EFI index forecasts from the ECMWF model > 0.8
ANAM extreme rain forecast
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: ECMWF (European Centre Model) and ANAM (National Meteorological Agency of Chad)
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Moyen Chari, Mandoul, Logone Oriental, Tandjilé, Mayo Kebbi West, Salamat
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: This trigger is the second stage of a sequenced activation following the seasonal preparedness trigger.
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Implementation of direct early actions; housing safety actions; distribution of prepositioned materials to 400 targeted households.

trigger_mechanism.description: The drought trigger mechanism is a dual-trigger system that combines hazard forecasting with dynamic vulnerability assessment. It requires both a meteorological drought indicator (SPI-12) and a food insecurity projection (IPC-based index) to reach specific thresholds within the same district.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: The stop mechanism is activated if situational analysis, monthly SPI-12 data, and FEWSNET projection updates indicate an improvement in the projected food security situation. The process is initiated by the FbF/EAP Manager and confirmed by the DRM Directors.

trigger_statement_1.statement: When ICPAC issues an SPI-12 forecast of less than -1 for a district AND the FEWSNET food insecurity projection reaches at least 0.7 in its derived population-weighted index in the same district, then Anticipatory Actions will be triggered in the district.
thresholds: SPI-12 forecast of less than -1
FEWSNET food insecurity projection of at least 0.7 in its derived population-weighted index
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: ICPAC (for SPI-12) and FEWSNET (for Food Insecurity projection)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Districts in Somalia
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Early warning communication and advisory services (destocking, water conservation), rehabilitation of water points, and multi-purpose cash transfers. Readiness activities include yearly refresher trainings for volunteers in Cash, WASH, and Early Warning Communication.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP is activated based on a 7-day weather forecast from Kyrgyzhydromet with a lead time of four days. The process includes a confirmation step at 72 hours before the event to determine if the actions should proceed or be halted via a stop-mechanism.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: If the probability of the occurrence of a cold wave with a lead time of 72 hours is less than 75 per cent, the Stop Mechanism will be activated. This halts the distribution process, registration/verification of beneficiaries, and publication of press releases.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The EAP presented in this plan targets a cold wave and is triggered by a forecast provided by Kyrgyzhydromet with a lead time of four days.
thresholds: Forecast of a cold wave event
Lead time of 4 days
Probability of occurrence of at least 75% at 72 hours lead time (confirmation threshold)
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Kyrgyzhydromet (Hydrometeorological Service under the Ministry of Emergency Situations of the Kyrgyz Republic)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Kyrgyzstan (High-risk areas: Chuy, Naryn, Osh, Talas, Jalal-Abad, Batken, and Issyk-Kul provinces)
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Mobilizing RCSK FbF focal points, NDRT members and volunteers; beneficiary identification and registration; verification of vulnerable families; awareness raising; preparation of food parcels and non-food items (electrical heaters, blankets, mattresses, window insulation films); publication of press releases.

trigger_mechanism.description: The trigger mechanism is a multi-stage system based on rainfall forecasts. It consists of a Readiness Trigger at a 7-day lead time and an Activation Trigger at a 3-day lead time, both utilizing the same rainfall threshold but different forecast windows and geographic focuses.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Readiness Trigger: The readiness trigger will be met when the median ensemble member of the ECMWF forecast indicates that 24-hour rainfall totals will be 20mm or above, looking at a time window of 7 days ahead across western Yemen (including Hajjah Governorate). Activation Trigger: The activation trigger will be met when the median ensemble member of the ECMWF forecast indicates that 24-hour rainfall totals will be 20 mm or above, looking at a time window within 3 days (72 hours) over the northwestern part of the country (including Hajjah Governorate).
thresholds: 24-hour rainfall totals of 20mm or above
Median ensemble member of the ECMWF forecast
7-day lead time for Readiness
3-day (72 hours) lead time for Activation
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: ECMWF (European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts) in coordination with Yemen Metrology Department
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Western and Northwestern Yemen, specifically Hajjah Governorate (Abs district)
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: The Activation stage (3-day lead time) follows the Readiness stage (7-day lead time) based on updated forecasts.
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Activate branch disaster response team; disseminate Early Warning Early Action messaging and advisories; re-verify beneficiary lists for MPCA and shelter kits; notify financial service providers (FSPs) to begin preparedness; notify sandbag suppliers; procure and preposition first aid kits, stretchers, and emergency shelter/repair kits; coordinate with Cash and Market working group (CMWG), UNOCHA, and CCCM.

trigger_mechanism.description: The trigger mechanism is a multi-stage system based on rainfall forecasts from the ECMWF. It consists of a Readiness Trigger at a 7-day lead time and an Activation Trigger at a 3-day lead time, both utilizing the same rainfall intensity threshold to initiate progressively intensive early actions.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Readiness Trigger: The readiness trigger will be met when the median ensemble member of the ECMWF forecast indicates that 24-hour rainfall totals will be 20mm or above, looking at a time window of 7 days ahead across western Yemen (including Hajjah Governorate). Activation Trigger: The activation trigger will be met when the median ensemble member of the ECMWF forecast indicates that 24-hour rainfall totals will be 20 mm or above, looking at a time window within 3 days (72 hours) over the northwestern part of the country (including Hajjah Governorate).
thresholds: 24-hour rainfall totals of 20mm or above
Median ensemble member of the ECMWF forecast
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: ECMWF
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Western Yemen (Readiness) and Northwestern Yemen (Activation), specifically including Hajjah Governorate and IDP sites in Abs district.
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: The Activation Trigger (3 days) is a refinement of the Readiness Trigger (7 days) as the forecast window narrows.
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Activate branch disaster response team; disseminate Early Warning Early Action messaging and advisories; re-verify beneficiary lists for MPCA and shelter kits; notify financial service providers (FSPs) to begin preparedness; notify sandbag suppliers to prepare; distribute IEC materials (posters, brochures).

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP uses a multi-stage trigger system for riverine flooding. It begins with a Readiness Trigger (3-5 days lead time) based on GLOFAS return period forecasts or DHM/RIMES rainfall forecasts. This is followed by an Activation Trigger (48 hours lead time) based on DHM flood forecast bulletins or ICIMOD regional outlooks predicting specific water level thresholds at river gauging stations.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: Evacuation of the most vulnerable population and livestock is only implemented once the rivers surpass the danger level (based on real-time river status from DHM) and are in a rising trend in respective gauging stations.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The activation trigger for Karnali will be reached when the DHM flood forecast bulletin or regional flood outlook from ICIMOD or any special flood advisories from DHM predict the water level of Karnali in Chisapani to rise 1 metre above the existing danger level in the next 48 hours. The activation trigger for Babai and West Rapti River will be reached when the DHM flood forecast bulletin or regional flood outlook from ICIMOD or any special flood advisories from DHM predict water levels of Babai and West Rapti to rise to their existing danger levels in Chepang and Kusum station respectively in next 48 hours.
thresholds: GLOFAS predicts more than 2-year return period flow with a probability of 50% or more (3-5 days lead time)

Numerical weather prediction (NWP) from DHM/RIMES or special advisories predict extreme and widespread rainfall for the next 3 days, provided rivers are already flowing at stage level less than 2m from existing danger level
Karnali River (Chisapani station): Water level predicted to rise to 11.8m (1m above existing danger level of 10.8m) within 48 hours
West Rapti River (Kusum station): Water level predicted to rise to 7.8m (existing danger level) within 48 hours
Babai River (Chepang station): Water level predicted to rise to 6.8m (existing danger level) within 48 hours
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Department of Hydrology and Meteorology (DHM) Nepal, GLOFAS, ICIMOD, RIMES
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Karnali, Babai and West Rapti river basins (Chisapani, Chepang and Kusum stations) in Banke, Bardiya and Kailali districts, Nepal
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: The activation trigger (48h) is preceded by a readiness trigger (3-5 days). The rainfall-based readiness trigger is conditional on the river stage being within 2m of the danger level.
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Confirmation of the readiness trigger initiates field preparation for evacuation and relocation of prepositioned items. Specific actions include: identification and orientation of volunteers, mapping and pre-arrangement of evacuation centers/safe sites, simulation of evacuation processes, mapping of local vendors and pre-agreements, and prepositioning of shelter tool kits, relief items, and waterproof storage bags.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP uses a dual-trigger mechanism based on meteorological and hydrological forecasts. Trigger 1 focuses on the probability of a tropical storm's path entering the national emergency zone, while Trigger 2 focuses on the probability of river flooding exceeding a specific return period.

trigger_statement_1.statement: When the National Institute of Seismology, Volcanology, Meteorology and Hydrology (INSIVUMEH) of Guatemala or the National Hurricane Center (NOAA) issues a forecast with a 60% probability that the path of a tropical storm (63 km/hr) or greater, will enter the cyclone emergency zone of the Republic of Guatemala, with a waiting time of 3 to 5 days.
thresholds: 60% probability of tropical storm path entering the cyclone emergency zone
Wind speed of 63 km/hr or greater
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: INSIVUMEH or NOAA
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Cyclone emergency zone of the Republic of Guatemala
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Registration and/or validation of families for Multipurpose Cash Transfers (MCT), distribution of MCT to selected families, and publication of guidelines with key information/messages on social networks.

trigger_statement_2.statement: When the Global Flood Awareness System (GLoFAS) forecast exceeds a 50% probability for a 3-year return period in areas of high flood risk with a 3-day lead time.
thresholds: 50% probability for a 3-year return period
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Areas of high flood risk in Guatemala
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Registration and/or validation of families for Multipurpose Cash Transfers (MCT), distribution of MCT to selected families, and publication of guidelines with key information/messages on social networks.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP uses a dual-trigger mechanism for meteorological drought. It requires two criteria to be met in sequence: first, an El Niño warning (Trigger 1) which initiates monitoring and pre-activation, followed by a seasonal precipitation forecast below a specific percentile (Trigger 2) which leads to full activation.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: A 'stop mechanism' allows actions to be halted if an updated seasonal forecast does not confirm the Trigger 2 forecast.

trigger_statement_1.statement: When INSIVUMEH issues a bulletin or seasonal precipitation forecast from the month of June with 50% probability below the first tercile (33rd percentile) for the next 3 months.
thresholds: El Niño warning in area 3.4 for the next 3 months with a 70% probability based on the IRI forecast as of June
Seasonal precipitation forecast with 50% probability below the first tercile (33rd percentile) for the next 3 months
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: National Institute of Seismology, Volcanology, Meteorology and Hydrology (INSIVUMEH) and NOAA Climate Prediction Center (CPC/IRI)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Guatemalan Dry Corridor (Municipalities: Quetzaltenango, Chiquimula, Jalapa, Sacapulas, Retalhuleu, and San Lorenzo)
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: The activation (Trigger 2) is conditional upon the prior issuance of an El Niño warning (Trigger 1) with 70% probability.
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Monitoring/Pre-activation (Trigger 1): Socialization of information to the Management Team of the Guatemalan Red Cross and IFRC, verification of available inputs, and volunteer preparation. Activation (Trigger 2): Communication with National Society branches, definition of intervention areas, mapping of zones, and deployment of personnel.

trigger_mechanism.description: The trigger mechanism is a multi-stage alert system based on seismic and ground deformation monitoring. It consists of three alert levels (Yellow, Orange, Red) triggered by special bulletins from the Karthala Volcanological Observatory (OVK). The system monitors seismic crises, micro-deformation of the ground, and changes in gas composition (carbon dioxide).
