trigger_statement_1.statement: It includes three types of alerts that are activated after receipt of the special bulletins of level 1 for the yellow alert, level 2 for the orange alert and level 3 for the red alert, which are monitored through the periodic forecasts shared by OVK two weeks, four days and two days before the impact respectively for the yellow, the orange and the red alert. The early action trigger threshold is reached, when the CRCS receives the special orange alert bulletin (OVK-SB2) four days before the impact. The red alert is reached, when the CRCS receives the special level 3 bulletin (OVK-BS3).
thresholds: Yellow Alert (Level 1): Receipt of special bulletin OVK-SB1 approximately 2 weeks before impact
Orange Alert (Level 2): Receipt of special bulletin OVK-SB2 approximately 4 days before impact
Red Alert (Level 3): Receipt of special bulletin OVK-BS3 approximately 2 days before impact

Orange Alert Technical Criteria: Anomaly higher than normal (second-level seismic crisis, second level micro-deformation of the ground, and change in the composition of gases through the accumulation of carbon dioxide) that persists for several hours a day
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Observatoire Volcanologique du Karthala (OVK) / Centre National de Documentation et de la Recherche Scientifique des Comores
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Ngazidja island (Comoros), specifically the regions of Mbadjini, Hambou, Bambao, Itsandra, Washilli, and Dimani
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: The early action protocol follows a sequential alert level system where specific actions are tied to the progression from Yellow to Orange and Red alerts.
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Yellow phase: Sensitization activities and covering water sources. Orange phase: Distribution of sanitation, WASH, and dignity kits; technical support for site identification and evacuation; psychosocial support. Red phase: Distribution of dust masks and protective glasses to the most at-risk population before evacuation.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP uses a 2-step triggering process. The first step occurs in September for readiness and low-regret actions based on a seasonal forecast. The second step occurs in mid-January for full activation of food and water-related early actions based on observed drought indices from the preceding three months.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: The Disaster Management Coordinator will be responsible for the activation and the stop mechanism with guidance of forecast information from the Meteorological Department.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The trigger is characterized by a 2-step triggering process: one starting in September for readiness and low-regret actions to be triggered by “below to normal” forecast issued by Eswatini Meteorological Services and the second one in mid-January based on low CDI average observed over the OND season aimed at triggering food and water-related early actions.
thresholds: “below to normal” rainfall forecast issued by Eswatini Meteorological Services in September
low Composite Drought Index (CDI) average observed over the OND (October-November-December) season
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Eswatini Meteorological Services (EMS)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Most drought prone areas with less coping capabilities (Lowveld region)
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: The mid-January activation is conditional on the monitoring and readiness phase initiated in September.
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Readiness activities including constituency and chiefdom sensitizations, targeting, registration, and verification of beneficiaries. Full activation includes distribution of multi-purpose cash for food, conditional cash for garden fencing, seeds, and animal care kits, procurement and delivery of hay bales, and water trucking.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP uses a two-stage trigger mechanism consisting of a Pre-Activation stage and an Activation stage. It relies on a combination of official government warnings (BMD signals), meteorological forecasts of wind speed from multiple global and regional models, and impact-based analysis of potential household asset damage.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Stage I: Pre-Activation: 'When BMD issues a Signal 4 or above warning with a lead time of 72 hours or more' AND 'BMD / IMD / ECMWF / GFS / JTWC (at least two models) forecasts wind speeds of 125 km/h or greater in the coastal districts of Bangladesh with a lead time of 72 hours or more AND with a potential damage of 25% household asset of the respective Unions'. Stage II: Activation: 'When BMD issues a Signal 7 or above warning with a lead time of 30 hours or more' AND 'BMD / IMD forecasts wind speeds of 125 km/h or greater in the coastal districts of Bangladesh with a lead time of 30 hours or more AND with a potential damage of 25 per cent household asset of the respective Unions'.
thresholds: BMD Signal 4 or above (Pre-activation stage)
BMD Signal 7 or above (Activation stage)
Wind speeds of 125 km/h or greater
Potential damage of 25% household assets in respective Unions
Agreement of at least two forecast models (BMD, IMD, ECMWF, GFS, or JTWC)
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Bangladesh Meteorological Department (BMD), Indian Meteorological Department (IMD), ECMWF, GFS, JTWC
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: 14 coastal districts of Bangladesh
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: The Activation stage (30 hours lead time) follows the Pre-Activation stage (72 hours lead time) based on updated forecasts and higher warning signals.
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Early warning dissemination (approx. 150,000 people); transport arrangement to evacuate people and livestock to cyclone shelters; distribution of food (flattened rice, sugar/molasses, energy biscuits), drinking water, and ORS at shelters; provision of basic first aid and hygiene items; cyclone shelter management support (lighting and WASH).

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP is activated based on cyclone alerts from the National Meteorological Institute (INAM). When a forecast meets the defined threshold, the Technical Committee for Disaster Management (CTGC) meets to decide on an official disaster alert. CVM activates the EAP only following this official government announcement.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: If the cyclone changes track dramatically to the point where selected communities are unlikely to suffer impacts, distribution is stopped and materials are returned to the warehouse. This mechanism only applies if communities have not yet been notified and distributions have not begun.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The threshold or trigger for activation of this EAP will be a category 3 cyclone with an anticipated speed of 120 km/h or more at landfall, as indicated by INAM in their 72-hour forecast. This corresponds to an event with a return period of 5 years. In exceptional cases, the EAP may be activated below the trigger threshold of 120 km/h it means 100km/h based on expert consensus, if levels of vulnerability have significantly increased at the time of activation due to compounding risks which emerged after the finalization of the EAP (e.g. onset of a pandemic) or because the exposed area has recently been impacted by another natural extreme event and find itself in the process of recovery and reconstruction.
thresholds: Category 3 cyclone
Wind speed of 120 km/h or more at landfall
Return period of 5 years
Exceptional threshold of 100 km/h based on expert consensus for high vulnerability or compounding risks
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: National Meteorological Institute (INAM)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Coastal districts in northern and central Mozambique (maximum of 3 districts simultaneously)
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: Official announcement of a disaster alert by the Technical Committee for Disaster Management (CTGC)
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Monitoring by FbF focal points in INAM's Forecasting Department; CTGC meeting to discuss forecasts; activation of CVM volunteers; dissemination of information on the phenomenon; dissemination of messages on community radios.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP is activated based on a 72-hour forecast from the National Meteorological Institute (INAM). Activation occurs when a Category 3 cyclone with wind speeds of at least 120 km/h is predicted to make landfall. The process requires an official alert from the Technical Committee for Disaster Management (CTGC), of which the Mozambique Red Cross (CVM) is a member.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: If the cyclone changes track dramatically to the point where selected communities are unlikely to suffer any impacts, distribution will be stopped and materials returned to the warehouse. This stop mechanism only takes effect if the cyclone changes course before communities have been notified of impending support and/or distributions have begun.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The threshold or trigger for activation of this EAP will be a category 3 cyclone with an anticipated speed of 120 km/h or more at landfall, as indicated by INAM in their 72-hour forecast. This corresponds to an event with a return period of 5 years. In exceptional cases, the EAP may be activated below the trigger threshold of 120 km/h it means 100km/h based on expert consensus, if levels of vulnerability have significantly increased at the time of activation due to compounding risks which emerged after the finalization of the EAP (e.g. onset of a pandemic) or because the exposed area has recently been impacted by another natural extreme event and find itself in the process of recovery and reconstruction.
thresholds: Category 3 cyclone
Wind speed of 120 km/h or more at landfall
5-year return period
100 km/h wind speed (exceptional case for compounding risks or recent disaster impact)
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: National Meteorological Institute (INAM)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Coastal districts in northern and central Mozambique (maximum of 3 districts within a 120 km radius of forecasted landfall)
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: Activation is conditional on the official announcement of an alert by the Technical Committee for Disaster Management (CTGC). The exceptional 100 km/h trigger requires consensus between CVM and IFRC based on consultations with government partners and technical experts.
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Monitoring of triggers by FbF focal points at INAM; CTGC meeting to discuss forecasts; selection of focus districts based on vulnerability criteria; activation of CVM volunteers; dissemination of information via community radios; demonstration of house reinforcement; distribution of shelter kits and WASH materials (chlorine/buckets).

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP is activated based on hydro-meteorological warnings indicating that water levels corresponding to a five-year return period discharge will be reached at upstream reference stations. It utilizes a dual-trigger approach involving national hydrological forecasts and the GloFAS global model as an alternative to extend lead times.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: Activities and distributions will be stopped and materials returned to the warehouse if the flood characteristics change dramatically such that selected communities are unlikely to be impacted. This mechanism only applies if communities have not yet been notified and distributions have not begun.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The actions proposed will be activated on the basis of hydro-meteorological warnings indicating that the trigger level (water level correspondent to discharge of five-year return period at the river basin reference station) will be reached within 72 hours (3 days).
thresholds: Water level correspondent to discharge of five-year return period at the river basin reference station
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: National Directorate of Water Resources Management (DNGRH)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Limpopo, Buzi, Zambezi and Licungo hydrographic basins (specifically 12 districts in Gaza, Sofala, and Zambezia provinces)
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Monitoring of triggers by FbF focal points; Technical Committee on Disaster Management (CTGD) discussions; coordination with INGD for activation approval.

trigger_statement_2.statement: This EAP will also incorporate GloFAS as an alternative trigger for the Buzi and Licungo rivers, where the model demonstrates sufficient capabilities, providing a lead time of approximately 7 days for Buzi and Licungo. Despite the Limpopo River presenting indications lower than the previous ones, they are still sufficient for use, given its lead time of 3 to 7 days.
thresholds: GloFAS model indications of flood risk (aligned with 5-year return period discharge)
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Automated email monitoring set up by the REPRESA project; Climate Centre review of GloFAS model skill for Limpopo and Zambezi rivers.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP uses a dual-trigger mechanism for activation. Both a meteorological condition (Tropical Storm forecast) and a hydrological condition (Flood forecast) must be met simultaneously to trigger the priority early actions. The system relies on a 3-to-5-day lead time.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The activation statement will have 2 criteria (both must be met): 1. CENAOS or NOAA issues a forecast with a 60% probability of a tropical storm (34 knots) or greater reaching the warning area with a lead time of between 3 to 5 days. 2. When the GEOGLOWS/GloFAS forecast exceeds 50% probability for a 10-year return period in high flood hazard areas with a 3-day lead time.
thresholds: 60% probability of a tropical storm (34 knots) or greater reaching the warning area
GEOGLOWS/GloFAS forecast exceeds 50% probability for a 10-year return period in high flood hazard areas
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: CENAOS, NOAA, GEOGLOWS, GloFAS, ECMWF
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Honduras (specifically high flood hazard areas and municipalities identified in the flood risk index)
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: Both meteorological and hydrological criteria must be met simultaneously for activation.
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Readiness activities: Hiring of anticipation referent and GIS technician, development of simulations and workshops, purchase of satellite tool licenses, and socialization of the EAP. Prepositioning activities: CTP prepositioning (plastic/electronic code service), acquisition of 20 water quality kits, 2,000 buckets, family hygiene kits, and protective/visibility equipment for volunteers.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP uses a multi-stage trigger system based on forecasts from the National Meteorological Institute (IMN). Trigger 1 serves as a monitoring and pre-activation phase, while Trigger 2 initiates full activation. Trigger 2 can also be declared directly (bypassing Trigger 1) if specific rainfall and storm location conditions are met to avoid 'missed events'.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: If a forecast update is issued 2 days after Trigger 2 activation and indicates that cumulative rainfall will not exceed 300 mm for a 3-day horizon, the stop mechanism is activated and early actions are discontinued.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Information from the National Meteorological Institute (IMN), on the forecast of a tropical storm with a trajectory entering at least Zone 3 indicated in the IMN Emergency Protocol, with a 60% probability and a lead time of 5 days.
thresholds: Tropical storm trajectory entering at least Zone 3 (IMN Emergency Protocol)
60% probability
5-day lead time
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: National Meteorological Institute (IMN)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Zone 3 as defined in the IMN Emergency Protocol
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Monitoring of IMN updates; Technical meeting with IMN; GIS analysis and preparation of intervention map; Review of analysis with DINAGER; Coordination with COR and local committees; Reporting to National Society management; Coordination with local authorities; Establishing communication channels with the community; Financial, human, and logistical resource preparation.

trigger_statement_2.statement: Occurs when the IMN issues a forecast of extreme rainfall with a high probability of exceeding 400 mm of accumulated precipitation for a 5-day horizon, currently the EAP is activated. Trigger 2 may be declared directly when cumulative rainfall of between 300 and 400 mm is forecast, in association with the formation of a tropical depression in danger zone '1 or 2'.
thresholds: Accumulated precipitation exceeding 400 mm for a 5-day horizon
Accumulated rainfall between 300 and 400 mm associated with a tropical depression in danger zone 1 or 2
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Prioritized flood hazard zones and river basins in Costa Rica
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: Usually follows Trigger 1, but can be declared directly regardless of Trigger 1 status to mitigate risk of missed events.
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Execution of humanitarian aid delivery; Multi-purpose Cash Distribution.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP uses a multi-stage trigger system based on volcanic activity reports (Special Reports A, B, and C) issued by IGEPN. Trigger 1 focuses on awareness and preparation based on internal volcanic changes, while Trigger 2 focuses on fund requests and full activation based on eruptive events and ash fall modeling.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: The stop mechanism is defined by Special Report B. When this report indicates that the internal activity of the volcano (seismicity, degassing, and deformation) has decreased and stabilized, the intervention in the communities will be lifted.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Trigger 1: The EAP will activate actions of the Ecuadorian Red Cross in terms of awareness in high-risk areas with a spatial report A, indicating significant changes in the internal activity of a volcano. This type of report is issued when a significant change, increase in this case, in the internal activity of the volcano (seismicity, gas, deformation, etc.) is observed.
thresholds: Issuance of Special Report A
Significant increase in internal activity (seismicity, gas, deformation, etc.)
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: IGEPN (Geophysical Institute of the National Polytechnic)
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: Variable (can be months before an eruption; 2020 experience showed awareness from June to September)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: High-risk areas near volcanoes
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Implementation of Awareness Plan; Training for volunteers in volcanic ash monitoring and protection measures; Registration of potentially affected people; Prepositioning of Health and Livelihood Protection Kits in strategic warehouses (Tungurahua, Pichincha, Imbabura).

trigger_statement_2.statement: Trigger 2: The EAP will activate the request for funds with a special report B (Increase of parameters of internal activity of the volcano) and/or with a spatial report C, which indicates an eruptive event with an explosive index (VEI 3) with possible impact on the communities. The ASH3D Ash Fall and Dispersion Model of the IGEPN should indicate at least that the 2 mm ash fall in the communities is exceeded.
thresholds: Issuance of Special Report B (Increase of parameters)
Issuance of Special Report C (Eruptive event with VEI 3)
ASH3D or FALL3D model forecast exceeding 2 mm ash fall
Impact level 1: 2 to 5 mm ash fall
Impact level 2: 5 to 10 mm ash fall
Impact level 3: 10 to 300 mm ash fall
trigger_statement_2.lead_time: Short-term/Immediate (uses real-time information such as ash column height and direction)
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Communities prioritized by risk index based on ash fall dispersion models
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: Activation of Trigger 2 is typically preceded by the monitoring phase of Trigger 1, though Report B can be generated any time after Report A.
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Administrative and operational alert of the National Society; Distribution of Health Protection Kits (N95 masks, goggles); Distribution of Livelihood Protection Kits (plastic tarps, toolkits); Multisectoral distribution of Cash and Voucher Assistance (CVA) of approximately USD 200 (for ash fall >= 10 mm); Protection of water supply sources (jerrycans and tarps).

trigger_mechanism.description: The trigger system is based on an impact-based forecast tool (Extreme Temperature Categorization system) that correlates extreme temperature data with excess mortality. While the National Observatory of Athens (NOA) provides alerts for Categories 1 through 3, the sEAP only activates for high-severity Category 3 events. There is a monitoring phase for lower categories (soft triggers) where standard awareness activities are conducted.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The sEAP trigger will be reached when NOA issues a Heat Alert category 3, with a predicted excess mortality rate of 45% or higher, within a five-day lead time to implement the early action activities.
thresholds: Heat Alert Category 3
Predicted excess mortality rate of 45% or higher
5-day lead time
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: National Observatory of Athens (NOA) / Arsht-Rockefeller and Atlantic Council Extreme Temperature Categorization system
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Cities of Athens, Patras, and Thessaloniki
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Monitoring of Heat Alerts Category 1 and above; commencement of usual heat activities within existing capacity for alerts below the 45% threshold; investment in paid social media boosts when soft triggers are met.

trigger_mechanism.description: The activation system follows a multi-stage process starting with a watch signal based on SPI analysis. The first trigger is activated one month before the season based on seasonal SPI forecasts. A second activation is triggered one month after the start of the season based on agricultural drought signals (crop yield reduction).
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: If the moisture or Water Requirement Satisfaction Index (WRSI) is not showing the level of critical (not passed the threshold) a stop mechanism will be initiated.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The ERCS will activate the EAP with the first trigger (one month ahead of a season) when the seasonal forecast (provided by the ECMWF/ICPAC and EMI) indicated that more than 50% of the geographical area of a zone is predicted to be drier than normal conditions SPI<-1, and at least 40% probability of below normal for JJA season and 45% probability of below normal OND and MAM seasons with a 1-month lead time.
thresholds: More than 50% of the geographical area of a zone predicted to be drier than normal (SPI < -1)
At least 40% probability of below normal for JJA season
At least 45% probability of below normal for OND and MAM seasons
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: ECMWF/ICPAC and EMI
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: East and West Harerge, Afar Zone 1 and Zone 3, Northern Shewa, North and South Wollo, South Gonder, Southern Tigray, Somali (Afder, Dhawa, Dollo, Fafan, Korah, Liben and Shebelle zones), Borena, Guji, Erer, and East Bale zones
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: SPI-3 forecast used to warn Technical Working Group (TWG) and at-risk communities to perform 'community-owned' activities ahead of the season.

trigger_statement_2.statement: The second activation will be triggered (one month after the start of the season) when the crop yield reduction is predicted to be more than 50% based on LEAP index
thresholds: Crop yield reduction predicted to be more than 50% based on LEAP index (Water Requirement Satisfaction Index for a specific crop)
trigger_statement_2.lead_time: 1 month after the start of the season
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Drought prone zones in Ethiopia (Belg receiving, Northern pastorals, and Southern pastoral livelihood zones)
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: Activated after the first trigger and four weeks after the start of the season if agricultural drought signals pass the threshold.
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Automated messages sent to TWG members; EDRMC calls urgent TWG meeting; official implementation of early actions starts; dissemination of early warning information; rehabilitation of water facilities; promotion of food saving and drought-tolerant crops; vaccination and pre-stocking of vet medicines.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP uses a two-stage trigger mechanism consisting of a pre-activation stage and an activation stage. Both stages share the same physical thresholds but differ in forecast sources and lead times. The system requires monitoring of temperature and heat index forecasts.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: The stop mechanism is set at Day 4, 3, and 2 before the potential occurrence. If the forecast 2 to 3 days prior indicates the activation trigger will not be hit, the committee stops the activation. However, if cash distribution or other early actions have already started, implementation continues.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Pre-activation: to activate the pre-activation trigger, the forecast (from ECMWF and/or GFS) needs to meet two thresholds – a temperature of 38°C or more for 2 two consecutive days, and a heat index of 38 or more for two consecutive days. The expected lead time is 5–7 days. Activation: the activation trigger has a same threshold as pre-activation. However, the source of the forecast is BMD and either ECMWF or GFS; and the expected lead time is 2-3 days.
thresholds: Temperature of 38°C or more for 2 consecutive days
Heat index of 38 or more for 2 consecutive days
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: BMD (Bangladesh Meteorological Department), ECMWF, and GFS
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Dhaka City (North and South), specifically targeting high-impact Thanas and slums
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: The Activation stage (2-3 days lead time) is conditional on the forecast being confirmed by the Bangladesh Meteorological Department (BMD) in addition to ECMWF or GFS after the Pre-activation threshold has been monitored.
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Mapping Thanas expected to experience most impact; beneficiary selection; MPCG (Multi-purpose Cash Grant) distribution; ambulance support for referral cases; first aid services; cooling station/centre setup; distribution of safe drinking water and saline; mass awareness messaging through miking.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP is activated based on a 7-day forecast from Kyrgyzhydromet. A 72-hour forecast is then used as a confirmation step. If the probability of the heatwave at the 72-hour mark falls below a specific threshold, a stop mechanism is activated to halt early actions.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: If the probability of the occurrence of a heatwave with a lead time of 72 hours is less than 75%, the Stop Mechanism is activated by the RCSK Head of the Disaster Management Department. Implementation of early actions is then stopped unless a subsequent forecast confirms the heatwave.

trigger_statement_1.statement: the seven-day forecast of Kyrgyzhydromet indicates that temperature will exceed the 85th percentile for three (3) and more consecutive days during June – August throughout the life cycle of the EAP with a lead time of four (4) days for the selected local points.
thresholds: Temperature exceeds the 85th percentile
Duration of 3 or more consecutive days
Occurs during the months of June, July, or August
Lead time of 4 days
Confirmation threshold: 72-hour forecast probability must be 75% or higher
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Kyrgyzhydromet
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Selected local points in Chui, Issyk-Kul, Talas, Batken, Jalal-Abad and Osh provinces
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Distribution of food parcels and hygiene kits for families below the poverty line; distribution of coloring books and pencils for children; installation of air conditioners in care homes and orphanages; installation of information boards; conducting information campaigns (first aid master classes, videos); early warning via SMS.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP uses a multi-stage trigger system based on flood bulletins from the Flood Forecasting Division (FFD). An initial activation trigger is reached 3-5 days in advance to start early warnings and beneficiary registration. A second confirmation stage occurs 24-48 hours before the event to trigger the actual cash distribution.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: A stop mechanism is in place for the distribution of cash if the 24-48 hour lead time bulletins (Bulletin A or B) do not confirm the very high flooding threshold of 150,000 cusecs at Nowshera station.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The activation trigger will be reached when flood bulletin C (Weekly River’s Catchments Forecast) and significant flood warning/advisories from FFD/PMD predicts very high to exceptionally high flooding with river flow above 150,000 cusecs at Nowshera station of Kabul River with a lead time ranging from 3-5 days. However, the distribution of cash to registered beneficiaries will be implemented within 24hr - 48hr lead time when the flood bulletin A (Qualitative Flood Forecast) or flood bulletin B (Quantitative flood forecast) from FFD/PMD confirms a very high-level flooding with flow above 150,000 cusecs at Nowshera station of Kabul River within the next 48hrs.
thresholds: River flow above 150,000 cusecs at Nowshera station
Very high to exceptionally high flooding category
Confirmation of 150,000 cusecs threshold within 24-48 hours for cash disbursement
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Flood Forecasting Division (FFD) of Pakistan Meteorological Department (PMD)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Kabul River basin, specifically Nowshera station
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Dissemination of early warning messages; identification of most vulnerable communities; validation/registration of beneficiaries; funds disbursement to financial service providers (FSPs) and retailers.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP uses a multi-stage trigger process for the October-November-December (OND) rainy season. It begins with a meteorological forecast (SPI), followed by a risk-based ranking using an IBF dashboard (incorporating IPC projections), and a final operational filter using NDMA data to ensure the intervention is anticipatory (targeting counties in 'alert' or 'normal' status rather than 'alarm' or 'emergency').

trigger_statement_1.statement: This EAP will be triggered for the 23 ASAL counties of Kenya where Standardised Precipitation Index (SPI) forecast for OND from KMD indicates SPI value of below -0.98 with at least 33% chance of occurrence, in at least 3 counties.
thresholds: Standardised Precipitation Index (SPI) value below -0.98
At least 33% chance of occurrence
Condition met in at least 3 of the 23 ASAL counties
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Kenya Meteorological Department (KMD), National Drought Management Authority (NDMA), IBF dashboard
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: 23 Arid and Semi-Arid (ASAL) counties of Kenya
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: The trigger is conditional on the current drought classification by NDMA; counties already in 'alarm' or 'emergency' states are excluded to ensure actions are anticipatory, focusing on those in 'alert' or 'normal' states.
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Dissemination of early warning information (Radio and SMS); WASH needs and feasibility assessments; Rapid assessment of water facility functionality; Pre-Crisis Market Analysis (conducted 1.5 months before the season); Advocacy on water harvesting and pasture management; Activation of Water Management Committees.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP utilizes a two-stage trigger system based on an Impact Based Forecast (IBF) Drought model. The model monitors five meteorological indicators (including ENSO, CHIRPS, and VCI) starting in September to provide up to 7 months of lead time. The first stage triggers low-investment mitigation, while the second stage triggers food security interventions.

trigger_statement_1.statement: A forecast of an El Nino event, with an impact level corresponding to a once-in-six-year event, will act as the first trigger for low investment Early Actions (Early warning dissemination, drought tolerant seed distributions, and livestock dosing).
thresholds: Forecast of an El Nino event
Impact level corresponding to a once-in-six-year event
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: IBF Drought model (utilizing ENSO forecasts, CHIRPS Data, and Vegetation Condition Index), Meteorological Services Department (MSD)
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: 7 months (model runs monthly starting in September; actions initiated in October)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Zimbabwe (target districts)
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Early warning communication, distribution of drought-tolerant short-season certified seed varieties, and livestock dosing support (vaccination and dipping).

trigger_statement_2.statement: A forecast of IPC 4 conditions in the FEWSnet Food Security Forecast Reports in Both March and June will trigger the second set of early actions that address drought-induced food insecurity (livestock support, Multi-Purpose Cash Transfers, and school supplemental feeding)
thresholds: IPC 4 conditions in FEWSnet Food Security Forecast Reports in both March and June
IBF model detects a drought by April (if Trigger 1 was not met)
Drought declared by the Government of Zimbabwe (if Trigger 1 was not met)
2nd round of crop assessments by Agritex indicating a poor agricultural season or failed harvest
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: FEWSnet, Agritex, IBF Model, and Government of Zimbabwe
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: Normally activated following the activation of the first trigger. If the first trigger is not activated, the second trigger will only activate if the IBF model detects a drought by April and a drought is declared by the Government of Zimbabwe.
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Livestock dosing support, Multi-Purpose Cash/Voucher Assistance (65 USD per round for three months), and school supplemental feeding (CSB and cooking materials) in collaboration with the Ministry of Education.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP is activated based on a dual-trigger system requiring both an ENSO alert and a specific precipitation deficit forecast. Monitoring begins three months in advance with monthly evaluations.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: The stop mechanism (interruption mechanism) is triggered by the update of the quarterly forecast of the next month's climate outlook.

trigger_statement_1.statement: When COPECO/CENAOS issues an alert warning of "El Niño" in area 3.4, for the next 3 months with a 60% probability based on the IRI forecast from the OND quarter (year -1) and except for AMJ and MJJ quarters (Predictability barrier).
thresholds: El Niño alert in area 3.4
60% probability
3-month forecast window
Based on IRI forecast from OND quarter
Excluding AMJ and MJJ quarters (predictability barrier)
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: COPECO/CENAOS, CPC/IRI, NOAA
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: ENSO Area 3.4
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: Both Trigger 1 and Trigger 2 are required for the activation declaration
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Monitoring of meteorological conditions three months in advance and monthly control mechanism evaluation

trigger_statement_2.statement: When COPECO/CENAOS issues a climate outlook bulletin where a serious precipitation deficiency is forecast when the accumulated rainfall for the next 3 months is between the 10th and 20th percentile in the dry corridor starting in the (March-May) MAM quarter (year 1) with a probability from greater to 60%.
thresholds: Serious precipitation deficiency
Accumulated rainfall between 10th and 20th percentile
Probability greater than 60%
Starting in the MAM (March-May) quarter
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: Both Trigger 1 and Trigger 2 are required for the activation declaration
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Monitoring of meteorological conditions three months in advance and monthly control mechanism evaluation

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP uses a two-tiered trigger system. A pre-activation trigger is initiated in September based on seasonal forecasts, followed by a second activation trigger in January based on observed rainfall and vulnerability projections.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: The stoppage of the activation will be initiated by the EAP Manager who, upon assessing and confirmation of the changes, will recommend concurrently to the Programme Director and IFRC for the latter to order the activation stoppage.

trigger_statement_1.statement: LRCS will activate a two-tiered trigger. The pre-activation trigger is reached when LMS issues the seasonal outlook in September with below normal rainfall and this will initiate the dissemination of early warning messaging (EWM), and preparedness and monitoring measures of the upcoming conditions. The second trigger is reached when all following three conditions are met: (i) the first trigger was activated in September, (ii) the October, November, December (OND) rainfall was indeed below normal (iii) the Vulnerability Assessment Analysis report (by LVAC) issued in January projects 20% of the population in drought-induced IPC Phase 3 and 4 in January in anticipation of the March/April main harvests for the next six months.
thresholds: LMS seasonal outlook in September indicates below normal rainfall
October, November, December (OND) rainfall is below normal
LVAC report projects 20% of the population in drought-induced IPC Phase 3 and 4
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Lesotho Meteorological Services (LMS) and Lesotho Vulnerability Assessment Committee (LVAC)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Southern lowlands and Senqu valley, Lesotho
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: The second trigger (activation) is conditional on the first trigger (pre-activation) being met in September and the OND rainfall being below normal.
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Dissemination of early warning messaging (EWM) to 20,560 people, preparedness and monitoring measures of the upcoming conditions, and training of community-based organizations in EWM dissemination.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP is activated based on a 4-day (96-hour) weather forecast provided by the Hydromet of Tajikistan and a CoES alert. The trigger is reached when specific temperature thresholds (percentiles) are forecasted to be exceeded for at least three consecutive days in designated regions.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: The Stop mechanism will be activated if the probability of the occurrence of a cold wave is less than 85% with a lead-time of 48 hours. The FbF coordinator proposes the stop mechanism based on consultations with Hydromet, and the RCST Head of DM department endorses it.

trigger_statement_1.statement: This EAP will be triggered based on forecast to be provided by the Hydromet of Tajikistan and CoES alert, if temperatures in GBAO exceed the 1 percentile/PCTL [at temperature of below -39.0°C] and in all other areas of DRS, Sughd and Khalton exceed 2 percentile/PCTL [at temperature of below -21.1°C] for 3 or more consecutive days based on the 4-days [96 hours] weather forecast with the 4 days of lead-time that the RCST will have to prepare for an extreme cold wave before it strikes.
thresholds: Temperatures in GBAO below -39.0°C (1st percentile)
Temperatures in DRS, Sughd, and Khatlon below -21.1°C (2nd percentile)
Duration of 3 or more consecutive days
4-day (96 hours) weather forecast
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Hydromet of Tajikistan and Committee on Emergency Situations (CoES)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Tajikistan (Gorno-Badakhshan Autonomous Oblast [GBAO], Districts of Republican Subordination [DRS], Sughd and Khatlon provinces)
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Spread of awareness messages and alerts; provision of Non-Food Items (NFIs) including electric oil heaters, materials for windows and floor thermal insulation, and thermos flasks; provision of essential food commodities for a family of 5 to cover the first seven days; provision of First Aid support by LDMCs in case of hypothermia or frostbite.

trigger_mechanism.description: The trigger mechanism is a multi-stage process based on Kazhydromet forecasts. A 7-day temperature forecast triggers the activation of the simplified EAP and preparation activities, while a 3-day map alert initiates the specific early action activities. The trigger is based on specific temperature thresholds combined with precipitation, wind speed, and duration.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Orange level of weather or higher threat according to the Kazhydromet, which means: If the 7-day temperature forecast of Kazhydromet shows the minimum temperature will go below -40˚C (-35 ˚C in Karaganada region) with precipitation and increased speed of wind and such conditions persist for at least two days in any district... If the 3-day map alert of Kazhydromet forecast temperatures consistent with the table below in any targeted district the early action activities will be initiated.
thresholds: Minimum temperature below -40°C (Northern Kazakhstan, Akmola, Kostanay, Pavlodar, Eastern Kazakhstan, and Abay regions)
Minimum temperature below -35°C (Karaganda region)
Presence of precipitation
Increased speed of wind
Conditions persist for at least two days
Orange level of weather threat or higher
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Kazhydromet
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: 7 days for activation/preparation, 3 days for action initiation
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Northern Kazakhstan, Pavlodar, Kostanay, Eastern Kazakhstan, Abay, Akmola, Karaganda regions, and Astana city
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: National Society starts preparation for activation and continues monitoring; pre-contracting of food service providers; mapping of homeless gathering places; awareness raising about food distribution points and social adaptation centers; agreements with local police and social services for transportation; preparing databases of vulnerable elderly, single mothers, and people with special needs; mapping bus stations, truck parking, and gas stations.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP is activated based on weather forecasts from Tajik Hydromet. Activation occurs when forecasted temperatures exceed specific regional thresholds for 4 consecutive days during the summer period (July-August), with a lead time of 5 days.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: If the heatwave changes track dramatically before communities are notified or distributions begin, the operation is stopped and materials are returned to storage. If the path shifts after distribution starts, RCST assesses re-routing or continues if the community is still at risk.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The trigger for this EAP will be activated when Hydromet issues a forecast of the day temperature exceeding 39.5°C in the North and 43.5°C in the South for 4 consecutive days in the period of July-August.
thresholds: Day temperature exceeding 39.5°C in the North for 4 consecutive days
Day temperature exceeding 43.5°C in the South for 4 consecutive days
Specific district thresholds based on 90th percentile (ranging from 35°C to 43.5°C)
Forecast probability of 78%-85% (Bagrov model)
Return period of 5 years or less
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Tajik Hydromet (using Bagrov, ECMWF, COSMO, and WRF models)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Tajikistan (Districts: Kabodiyon, Nosiri Khusrav, Shahritus, Rudaki, Bokhtar, Kumsangir, Panj, Dushanbe, Hissor, Shahrinav, Tursunzoda, Vahdat, Farkhor, Kulob, Vose, Asht, Khujand, Mastcho, Zafarobod, B. Gafurov, Darvoz, Istaravshan, Penjikent, Ayni, Khovaling, Muminobod, Shurobod, Faizobod, Rasht, Tojikobod, Khorog, Rushon, Ishkoshim, Vanj, Iskandarkul, Mastchoi Kuhi, Lakhsh, Navobod)
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Awareness broadcasting (starts at 120h lead time), safety measures tuition (held at <48h lead time), notification of IFRC and CoES, and mobilization of NDRTs and volunteers.

trigger_mechanism.description: The sEAP uses a dual-trigger system requiring both observed conditions (specific temperature and humidity thresholds) and forecast criteria (DHM red alerts or 99th percentile forecasts) to be met simultaneously for activation in specific cities.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The simplified Early Action Protocol (sEAP) will be activated in a respective city/municipality of the southern Terai region of Nepal when both of the observed conditions and forecast criteria are met: 1. Observed Conditions: o Daily maximum temperature (Tmax) exceeding - 41°C in Nepalgunj - 40.5°C in Dhangadi - 37.5 °C in Biratnagar - 40.5°C in Siddharthanagar o Relative humidity (Rh) of 45 per cent or higher in the respective city for which observed condition for Tmax is met. 2. Forecast Criteria: In addition to the observed conditions, at least one of the following forecast criteria must be met for the same city/municipality for which both the aforementioned observed condition (Tmax and Rh) is met: o Criteria 1: DHM issues a red alert heatwave bulletin (indicating "take action") for the next 3 days in the target city or its associated district. o Criteria 2: Numerical Weather Prediction (NWP) product from DHM forecasts daily maximum temperature (Tmax) above the 99th percentile threshold in the target cities/municipalities for the next 3 consecutive days.
thresholds: Nepalgunj: Daily maximum temperature (Tmax) > 41°C
Dhangadi: Daily maximum temperature (Tmax) > 40.5°C
Biratnagar: Daily maximum temperature (Tmax) > 37.5°C
Siddharthanagar: Daily maximum temperature (Tmax) > 40.5°C
Relative humidity (Rh) >= 45% in the respective city
DHM Red Alert heatwave bulletin ('take action') for the next 3 days
NWP forecast Tmax > 99th percentile for 3 consecutive days
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Department of Hydrology and Meteorology (DHM)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Southern Terai region of Nepal (Nepalgunj, Dhangadi, Biratnagar, Siddharthanagar)
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: Forecast criteria must be met in addition to observed conditions (Tmax and Rh) for the same city/municipality.
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Awareness and community sensitization, volunteer mobilization for beneficiary registration, training NRCS volunteers and staff on CVA, standby agreements with telecommunication and catering services, and coordination meetings with municipalities.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP uses a three-trigger system based on seasonal rainfall forecasts, forage biomass assessments, and food security indicators (Cadre Harmonisé). Trigger 1 is activated in April/May based on rainfall forecasts, while Triggers 2 and 3 are activated in November based on fodder deficits and food security phases respectively.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: A deactivation mechanism will apply if updated forecasts or satellite monitoring show a significant improvement in rainfall or vegetation cover before the window for early action closes.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The CRN will launch a first phase of early action in April/May based on a forecast of 40% or more below-normal rainfall provided by the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF). When the ECMWF forecasts indicate, in April, a probability of 40% or more of having below-normal rainfall totals over the period July to September in a region or department, we will coordinate with the national meteorological service to carry out a downscaling.
thresholds: 40% or more probability of below-normal rainfall totals for the period July to September
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) and National Directorate of Meteorology (DMN)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Region or department, downscaled to communes and villages
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Awareness messages (Radio, Megaphone); Vaccination coupled with vitamins, minerals, and deworming; Distribution of drought-adapted seeds (millet and cowpeas); Post-Distribution Evaluation.

trigger_statement_2.statement: When the results of the Ministry of Livestock's forage biomass assessment, carried out in November, indicate a fodder deficit of up to 40% or more in a locality (commune or village), the NS will activate the second trigger and intervene in these localities with the specific early actions.
thresholds: Fodder deficit of 40% or more
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Awareness messages (Radio, Megaphone); Conditional cash transfer for livestock owners to access cereals and livestock feed; Vaccination/Deworming.

trigger_statement_3.statement: Finally, if the November Cadre Harmonisé results indicate that a region will be in IPC Phase 3 or higher due to drought, the NS will anticipate a difficult lean season. To do this, NRCS will use the data from the evaluation of the agricultural season of the Ministry of Agriculture to determine the communes and villages in deficit in the concerned region.
thresholds: IPC Phase 3 or higher in Cadre Harmonisé
Agricultural season evaluation showing deficit in communes/villages
trigger_statement_3.source_authority: Cadre Harmonisé and Ministry of Agriculture
trigger_statement_3.geographic_scope: Region, downscaled to communes and villages in deficit
trigger_statement_3.preliminary_actions: Awareness messages (Radio, Megaphone); Conditional cash transfer allowing the poorest households to access cereals free of charge.

trigger_mechanism.description: The trigger mechanism is a multi-stage system aligned with the National Anticipatory Action Framework for Tropical Cyclones in Fiji. It utilizes a combination of wind speed forecasts and population exposure thresholds across two lead-time stages (Readiness and Action), plus a post-event observational rainfall trigger.

trigger_statement_1.statement: This simplified EAP will be triggered by a tropical cyclone that is forecasted by the Regional Specialized Meteorological Centre (RSMC) in Nadi to cause winds of at least 64 knots in zones where at least 5,000 people lives. The trigger comprises 2 stages, each of which is triggered based on the lead time of the points in the forecast: 1. Readiness trigger: If the wind field indicated by the 120-hour forecast meets the trigger conditions, the readiness trigger is met. 2. Action trigger: If the wind field indicated by the forecast up to a lead time of 72 hours meets the trigger conditions, the activation trigger is met.
thresholds: Winds of at least 64 knots (Category 3 on the Australian scale)
Zones where at least 5,000 people live (based on WorldPop 2020)
120-hour forecast for Readiness stage
72-hour forecast for Action stage
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Regional Specialized Meteorological Centre (RSMC) Nadi / Fiji Meteorological Services (FMS)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: National (Fiji)
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Activation of internal processes for fund release, prepositioning of funds to divisional teams, notification of logistics providers, movement of staff and volunteers, checking pre-positioned items (SSKs, jerry cans, soap), stakeholder coordination via NDMO, and confirmation of target communities/households.

trigger_statement_2.statement: The National AA Framework also includes a third trigger, which is a post event observational trigger: If the average rainfall over the whole country during two consecutive days meets the threshold (190 mm), the observational trigger is activated.
thresholds: Average rainfall of 190 mm over the whole country during two consecutive days
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Fiji Red Cross will seek rapid response funding from the DREF Response Pillar to conduct its pre-agreed actions.
